sentences.text: Congregation elders oversee formal discipline within the Jehovah's Witnesses community.

When a baptized member faces accusations of serious wrongdoing—typically involving sexual misconduct or apostasy by challenging Jehovah's Witness doctrines—a judicial committee is created to assess the situation.
This committee determines guilt, offers help, and may impose disciplinary measures.
The most severe form of discipline is disfellowshipping, or shunning, which is applied when the offender is seen as unrepentant.
Communication with disfellowshipped individuals is restricted to direct family members within the same household and congregation elders who may extend an invitation for reinstatement.
Business interactions can continue if there is a contractual or financial obligation.

The organization teaches that avoiding social and spiritual interactions with disfellowshipped members preserves the congregation's spiritual integrity and encourages the shunned individual to "come to his senses," recognize the gravity of their actions, and consider returning to Jehovah.

Shunning also serves as a deterrent against dissent within the community. Individuals who formally resign, or disassociate, are labeled as wicked in Watch Tower Society publications and are similarly shunned.
Disfellowshipped individuals can be reinstated if they later exhibit repentance, evaluated by the same congregation's elders.
Less severe than disfellowshipping, reproof is given to a repentant baptized Witness guilty of serious sin.
Although temporarily losing certain service privileges, the reproved member retains full social and spiritual fellowship.
Marking, which reduces social interaction but not spiritual fellowship, is applied to members who persist in actions violating Bible principles without committing a serious sin.
Copper, naturally found as native copper, has been familiar to some of the earliest known civilizations.
Its use dates back at least 10,000 years, with its discovery estimated around 9000 BC in the Middle East.
A copper pendant from northern Iraq, dating to 8700 BC, supports this timeline.
Before the use of copper, gold and meteoric iron were the only metals known to humans.
The development of copper metallurgy likely unfolded as follows: 1) cold working of native copper, 2) annealing, 3) smelting, and 4) the lost wax technique.
In southeastern Anatolia, these methods appeared almost simultaneously at the start of the Neolithic era around 7500 BC.
Much like agriculture, copper smelting emerged independently in several regions.
It likely arose in China before 2800 BC, in Central America around 600 AD, and in West Africa during the 9th or 10th century AD.
Investment casting originated between 4500–4000 BC in Southeast Asia, and carbon dating has positioned mining activity at Alderley Edge in Cheshire, UK, between 2280 and 1890 BC.
Ötzi the Iceman, dating from 3300–3200 BC, was discovered with an axe featuring a copper head that was 99.7% pure.
The high arsenic levels in his hair imply his involvement in copper smelting. Experience with copper paved the way for developments in other metals, notably leading to the discovery of iron smelting.
The Old Copper Complex in Michigan and Wisconsin produced copper between 6000 and 3000 BC.
Natural bronze, a type of copper from ores rich in silicon, arsenic, and occasionally tin, became common in the Balkans around 5500 BC.[citation needed]
Research across various traditions increasingly uses the concept of identity to explore different phenomena.
One significant area where identity and its construction play a role is in occupational settings—a challenge that becomes even more difficult in stigmatized jobs or "dirty work" (Hughes, 1951).
According to Tracy and Trethewey (2005), people are drawn to or avoid certain jobs based partly on whether those roles affirm their "preferred organizational self" (Tracy & Trethewey 2005, p. 169).

Some occupations carry specific stigmas or levels of esteem. For instance, Tracy explores how correctional officers struggle against the stigma of being perceived as "glorified maids" (Tracy & Trethewey 2005).
The process through which individuals justify and assign value to their occupational choices affects their workplace satisfaction and overall quality of life (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 33).
Those in stigmatized occupations must find ways to shape an identity they can accept.
"Crafting a positive sense of self at work is more challenging when one's work is considered 'dirty' by societal standards" (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 7).
Engaging in "taint management" goes beyond simply allowing an employee to feel good about their job.

If employees face societal doubts about the legitimacy of their work and face challenges in reframing it as honorable, they may resort to blaming the client as a way to affirm their identity (Tracy & Scott 2006, p. 33).
The term "house music" is said to have originated from The Warehouse, a Chicago club that operated from 1977 to 1983.
The Warehouse attracted a primarily black and gay crowd, who came to dance to the music of Frankie Knuckles, the club's resident DJ, affectionately known as the "godfather of house."
When The Warehouse closed in 1983, Knuckles opened a new club, The Power Plant, drawing the crowds there.

In the Channel 4 documentary "Pump Up The Volume," Knuckles recalls first encountering the term "house music" when he saw a sign reading "we play house music" in the window of a bar on Chicago's South Side.
Someone in his car humorously remarked, "That's the kind of music you play at the Warehouse!

", and they all laughed. Leonard "Remix" Roy, a South-Side Chicago DJ, claims in self-published statements that he put up such a sign in a tavern window, referring to the music people typically listened to at home, specifically his mother's soul and disco records, which he incorporated into his sets.
Farley Jackmaster Funk recounted, "In 1982, I was DJing at The Playground, and Leonard 'Remix' Roy visited from his rival club, The Rink.
He came to my DJ booth and told me, 'I've got the gimmick that's going to draw all your crowd to my club – it's called House music.'
Where he got that name or why he thought of it remains unknown; the answer is with him."
Early reviews of the show were mixed. Ken Tucker from Entertainment Weekly found "American Idol" to be wildly entertaining as television but insignificant as music.
In contrast, others were struck by the genuine talent the series showcased. Critics also described it as a "sadistic musical bake-off" and "a romp in humiliation."
Various aspects of the show drew criticism, particularly the product placements, which some considered blatant commercial tactics.

Karla Peterson of The San Diego Union-Tribune accused "American Idol" of being a "conniving multimedia monster" that mirrors and amplifies the vices of our culture into "a lump of reconstituted evil."
Additionally, the decision to have the first season's winner sing the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial on the first anniversary of the September 11 attacks in 2002 was poorly received.
Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post sarcastically remarked, "The terrorists have won," criticizing the commercialism and voting process.

She noted that the decision to "turn this important site into just another cog in the 'Great American Idol Marketing Mandala'" was placed in the hands of millions of young fans and a few avid phone-redialers, allegedly affecting the outcome despite assurances from Fox to the contrary.
In 1969, the Cubs, under manager Leo Durocher, held a commanding lead in the newly formed National League Eastern Division by mid-August.
On August 19, Ken Holtzman pitched a no-hitter, expanding their lead to 8½ games over the St. Louis Cardinals and 9½ games over the New York Mets.
By September 2, the Cubs had a record of 84-52, with the Mets trailing at 77-55. However, a Cubs' losing streak coincided with a Mets' winning streak.
The Cubs lost the last game of a series against Cincinnati, then returned home to face the revitalized Pittsburgh Pirates (who would finish third).
They lost the first two games 9-2 and 13-4 but were ahead in the ninth inning of the third game.
A win could have been a momentum booster before a critical series against the Mets.
Unfortunately, Willie Stargell hit a two-out, two-strike pitch from the Cubs' top reliever, Phil Regan, onto Sheffield Avenue, tying the game.
The Cubs eventually lost 7-5 in extra innings. Now on a four-game losing streak, they moved to Shea Stadium for a brief two-game series.

The Mets won both games, leaving the Cubs at 84-58, just ½ game ahead. Disaster continued in Philadelphia, where the 99-loss Phillies defeated the Cubs twice, extending their losing streak to eight games.

A crucial play in the second game on September 11 saw Cubs pitcher Dick Selma making an unexpected pickoff attempt to third baseman Ron Santo, who was too far from the base, leading to a throwing error that triggered a Phillies' rally.
After this loss, the Cubs were at 84-60, while the Mets surged ahead at 85-57 and never looked back.
The Cubs ended their losing streak in St. Louis, but the Mets were on a ten-game winning spree, and the Cubs, exhausted, faltered in all areas.
The Mets, who had lost a record 120 games seven years prior, went on to win the World Series.
Despite a solid 92-70 record, the Cubs are remembered for losing a staggering 17½ games in the standings to the Mets in the last quarter of the season.

Lutyens soon began to consider other locations for the new capital. The Delhi Town Planning Committee, created to plan this imperial city, included George Swinton as chairman, with John A. Brodie and Lutyens as members.
They initially submitted proposals for both northern and southern sites, but the Viceroy rejected these due to the high costs of acquiring the necessary land.
Originally, New Delhi's central axis was intended to run north-south, connecting the Viceroy's House with Paharganj.
In the project's early days, many tourists believed it was a gateway between Earth and Heaven.
However, due to space constraints and numerous heritage sites in the north, the committee eventually chose the southern site.
This location atop Raisina Hill, formerly Raisina Village, was selected for the Rashtrapati Bhawan, then known as the Viceroy's House.
The hill was directly opposite the Dinapanah citadel, which was also thought to be Indraprastha, the ancient heart of Delhi.
Consequently, the foundation stone was moved from the Delhi Durbar site of 1911–1912, where the Coronation Pillar once stood, and was placed in the forecourt walls of the Secretariat.
The Rajpath, formerly King's Way, extends from India Gate to the Rashtrapati Bhawan.

The Secretariat building, consisting of two blocks flanking the Rashtrapati Bhawan and housing Indian government ministries, along with the Parliament House, both designed by Herbert Baker, are located at Sansad Marg, running parallel to Rajpath.
Sleep does not impact the acquisition or recall of memories while we are awake; instead, its greatest influence is on memory consolidation.
During sleep, brain neural connections are strengthened, enhancing our ability to stabilize and retain memories.
Numerous studies have shown that sleep improves memory retention through active consolidation.
This process occurs during slow-wave sleep (SWS), where memories are reactivated but not all are enhanced.
During this reactivation, qualitative changes occur as memories are transferred into long-term storage.
While you sleep, the hippocampus replays the day's events for the neocortex to review and process, which ultimately moves them into long-term memory.
Insufficient sleep weakens these neural connections, making it difficult to learn and retain information.
Sleep deprivation not only hampers focus and learning efficiency but also risks the creation of false memories due to improper memory transfer.

Therefore, adequate sleep is crucial for optimal memory function. One of sleep's primary roles is believed to be enhancing information consolidation, as multiple studies have demonstrated that memory relies on adequate sleep between learning and testing.

Furthermore, neuroimaging studies have shown brain activation patterns in sleep that reflect those recorded during task learning, suggesting that new memories might be solidified through this rehearsal.
After acquiring the Master Sword, Link is freed from the magic that kept him in wolf form and gains the Shadow Crystal, enabling him to switch between forms at will.
Midna guides Link to the Mirror of Twilight in the Gerudo Desert, the sole gateway between the Twilight Realm and Hyrule.
They find the mirror shattered, and the Sages explain that Zant attempted to destroy it.
However, only the rightful ruler of the Twili can fully destroy the Mirror of Twilight, though Zant could only fragment it.
The Sages also reveal they had used the mirror a century earlier to exile Ganondorf, the Gerudo leader who tried to seize the Triforce, after failing to execute him.
With the aid of an underground resistance in Castle Town, Link and Midna embark on a quest to gather the mirror’s shards, confronting those corrupted by them.
Once the portal is reassembled, Midna is revealed as the rightful ruler of the Twilight Realm, displaced by Zant after he cursed her into her current form.
Upon confronting Zant, Link and Midna discover Zant's coup was facilitated by a pact with Ganondorf, who sought Zant's help to conquer Hyrule.
After defeating Zant, Midna retrieves the Fused Shadows and eliminates him, realizing only Ganondorf's demise can free her from her curse.
Returning to Hyrule, they confront Ganondorf in Hyrule Castle, where he holds a lifeless Zelda suspended.
Ganondorf battles Link by possessing Zelda’s body and later transforming into a beast, but Link overcomes him, allowing Midna to revive Zelda.
T. Gilmartin, a Professor of History at Maynooth in 1890, writes in Church History, Vol.
1, Ch XVII: The Arians sought the endorsement of an Ecumenical Council by organizing two separate councils.
Constantius called the Eastern bishops to convene at Seleucia in Isauria and the Western bishops at Rimini in Italy.
Before these meetings, the Arians held a preliminary conference at Sirmium to establish a consensus on a formula of faith.
They adopted the "Homoeon" creed, asserting that the Son was "like the Father."
The councils convened in the autumn of 359; Seleucia hosted 150 bishops, of whom 105 were semi-Arian.
These semi-Arians insisted on the "Homoiousion" creed (see: Homoiousian) and would accept nothing less.
Consequently, without any agreed creed, the Imperial Prefect disbanded the council.

Acacius, the leader of the "Homoean" faction, traveled to Constantinople, where the Sirmian creed was ratified by the "Home Synod," comprising bishops present at the Court, and a decree was issued against the semi-Arian leaders.
At Rimini, over 400 bishops attended, with 80 being Arian and the remainder orthodox.
The orthodox fathers were steadfast in accepting only the Nicene creed, while the others preferred the Sirmian creed.
Both parties sent delegations to the Emperor, expressing that an agreement was unlikely and requesting the bishops be allowed to return to their dioceses.
Constantius delayed his response for several months, intending to exhaust the orthodox bishops, and ultimately persuaded them to accept the Sirmian creed.
Following this Council, Jerome famously remarked, "The whole world groaned in astonishment to find itself Arian."
Several explanations have been offered for Yale's influence in national elections following the Vietnam War.
Many sources highlight the spirit of campus activism at Yale since the 1960s and Reverend William Sloane Coffin's intellectual impact on future candidates.

Yale President Richard Levin attributes this trend to Yale's mission of creating "a laboratory for future leaders," an institutional goal initiated during the tenures of Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster.

Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and current Duke University president, remarked, "We emphasize community orientation in admissions, and there's a strong tradition of volunteerism at Yale."

Historian Gaddis Smith notes "an ethos of organized activity" at Yale in the 20th century, leading John Kerry to head the Yale Political Union's Liberal Party, George Pataki the Conservative Party, and Joseph Lieberman to run the Yale Daily News.
Camille Paglia highlights a history of networking and elitism, suggesting, "It involves a web of friendships and affiliations built in school."
CNN reports that George W. Bush benefited from preferential admissions as "the son and grandson of alumni" and a "member of a politically influential family."

The New York Times' Elisabeth Bumiller and The Atlantic Monthly's James Fallows praise the culture of community and cooperation among students, faculty, and administration, which minimizes self-interest and enhances commitment to others.
Legal themes in *To Kill a Mockingbird*, especially in non-courtroom scenes, have captivated legal scholars.
Claudia Durst Johnson observes that legal experts have contributed more critical analysis in law journals than literary scholars in their respective publications.
The opening quote by 19th-century essayist Charles Lamb states: "Lawyers, I suppose, were children once."

Johnson highlights how even Scout and Jem's childhood involves negotiations, sealed by spitting on palms, and discussions with Atticus about laws, such as whether Bob Ewell should hunt and trap out of season.

People often defy social norms in symbolic courtrooms: Mr. Dolphus Raymond is ostracized for having a black partner and interracial children; Mayella Ewell is beaten by her father for kissing Tom Robinson; Boo Radley is socially isolated, a punishment more severe than any the legal system could impose.
Scout frequently violates social codes and laws and faces consequences for her actions.
She resists wearing frilly clothes, feeling that Aunt Alexandra’s "fanatical" insistence traps her in "a pink cotton penitentiary."

Johnson comments that the novel explores Jem and Scout's growing awareness of social codes and how these relationships, dictated by such codes, either fail or support the residents of their small world.
In late 1203, King John made an attempt to relieve Château Gaillard, which was under siege by Philip and was crucial in defending the eastern flank of Normandy.
He planned a coordinated effort involving both land and naval forces, which historians today regard as creative but too intricate for that era's military capabilities.
Philip's forces blocked John’s relief attempt, forcing him to pivot towards Brittany in a bid to divert Philip from eastern Normandy.
While John effectively ravaged much of Brittany, he failed to draw Philip's main focus away from Normandy.
Historians have differing views on John's military prowess during this campaign, with most recent assessments deeming it adequate but unremarkable.

John's position rapidly worsened. Philip and his predecessors had cultivated the eastern Normandy border for years, while Angevin authority in the south had been weakened when Richard granted away key castles earlier.
Additionally, John's use of mercenaries, known as routiers, in central regions further eroded his support, paving the way for a swift collapse of Angevin power.
John withdrew across the Channel in December, ordering a new defensive line west of Château Gaillard.
Château Gaillard fell in March 1204. The death of John's mother, Eleanor, the following month not only dealt him a personal loss but also jeopardized the vast Angevin alliances in southern France.
Philip bypassed the new defenses and struck at the core of the Duchy, meeting little resistance.
By August, Philip had seized control of Normandy and advanced south, capturing Anjou and Poitou. The Duchy of Aquitaine was John's last remaining possession on the continent.
A persistent theme in many of his films is the tension within parent-child relationships, often characterized by reluctant, absent, or ignorant parents, particularly fathers.
In "Hook," Peter Banning begins as a parent overly focused on his career but eventually regains his children's respect.
A well-known example of this theme is the absence of Elliott's father in "E.T."

In "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade," Indy has a strained relationship with his father, a professor of medieval literature, who seems more consumed by his research on the Holy Grail than by his son.
Indy's father mistakenly believes that his aloof parenting instilled "self-reliance," a view not shared by Indy.
Similarly, in "Schindler's List," Oskar Schindler is hesitant about starting a family.

"Munich" depicts Avner, who is separated from his wife and newborn daughter. However, there are exceptions, such as Brody in "Jaws," a dedicated family man, and John Anderton in "Minority Report," who is devastated by his son's disappearance.
This theme arguably reflects Spielberg's own experiences, as he was deeply affected by his parents' divorce and his father's absence.

Many of his protagonists come from broken families, as seen in "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial," where Elliott's mother is divorced, and "Catch Me If You Can," where Frank Abagnale's parents split early in the film. Less known is the reference to Tim's parents' divorce in "Jurassic Park."

Often, these divided families find resolution by the film's end. This theme of reluctant father figures is further illustrated in "Jurassic Park," where Tim looks to Dr. Alan Grant as a father figure.
Initially hesitant to embrace this role, Dr. Grant eventually softens, culminating in a scene where the children rest their heads on his shoulders.
The Qing dynasty maintained control over its outer regions, with the emperor serving as the Mongol khan, a patron of Tibetan Buddhism, and a protector of Muslims.

This approach shifted when Xinjiang was established as a province in 1884. During the era of The Great Game, Yaqub Beg, exploiting the Dungan revolt in northwest China, invaded Xinjiang from Central Asia with support from the British Empire and proclaimed himself ruler of Kashgaria.
The Qing court dispatched forces to defeat Yaqub Beg and reconquer Xinjiang, after which the political system of China proper was applied to the region.

The Kumul Khanate, which joined the Qing empire as a vassal after assisting in the defeat of the Zunghars in 1757, retained its status through the end of the dynasty and until 1930, even as Xinjiang transitioned into a province.
In the early 20th century, Britain sent an expeditionary force to Tibet, compelling the Tibetans to sign a treaty.
The Qing court responded by declaring Chinese sovereignty over Tibet, leading to the 1906 Anglo-Chinese Convention between Britain and China.
In this agreement, Britain vowed not to annex Tibetan territory or interfere in Tibet's administration, while China pledged to prevent any other foreign state from doing so.

Much like Xinjiang's conversion into a province, the Qing government also reorganized Manchuria into the "Three Northeast Provinces" and established the role of Viceroy of the Three Northeast Provinces to supervise these areas, increasing the number of regional viceroys to nine.

For its full North American launch, the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) was released in stages over several years, offering four different bundles: the Deluxe Set, the Control Deck, the Action Set, and the Power Set.
The Deluxe Set, priced at $199.99 (equivalent to $475 in 2016), included R.O.B., the NES Zapper light gun, two controllers, and two game packs: Gyromite and Duck Hunt.

The Basic Set was available for $89.99 without a game or $99.99 with "Super Mario Bros." The Action Set, introduced in 1988 for $149.99, featured the Control Deck, two controllers, an NES Zapper, and a dual game pack with Super Mario Bros. and Duck Hunt.
In 1989, the Power Set provided the console, two controllers, a NES Zapper, a Power Pad, and a triple game pack with Super Mario Bros., Duck Hunt, and World Class Track Meet.

By 1990, the Sports Set was available, including the console, an NES Satellite infrared wireless adapter, four controllers, and a dual game pack with Super Spike V'Ball and Nintendo World Cup. Additional bundles using the original NES console model came later.
The 1992 Challenge Set featured the console, two controllers, and a Super Mario Bros. 3 game pack for $89.99.
Initially released in 1987, the Basic Set was repackaged in 1992 for $89.99, including only the console and two controllers.
This iteration came without a game but included the Official Nintendo Player's Guide book, detailing all NES games available then.
Many cultures mark the transition to adult sexuality through specific biological or social milestones during adolescence.
Menarche, the onset of menstruation in females, and semenarche, the first ejaculation in males, often serve as key indicators in this transition.
However, an adolescent's sexual socialization is also heavily influenced by the cultural stance on teen and premarital sexual activity, which can be either restrictive or permissive.
Restrictive cultures discourage sexual activity in unmarried adolescents, at times enforcing separation of genders during development or using public shaming and physical punishment as deterrents.
In contrast, less restrictive cultures may allow more freedom for adolescent sexual expression and interaction between genders in both public and private settings.
While some less restrictive cultures may tolerate teenage sexual activity, they might still object to teenage pregnancy unless it occurs after marriage.
Permissive societies often accept and sometimes encourage overt sexual behavior among unmarried teens.
Regardless of cultural views, there tends to be a disparity in expectations for male and female expression of sexuality, which can be ingrained through legal means or social norms.
Additionally, lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender youths frequently face discrimination and bullying, and revealing their sexual identity can be distressing.
The spectrum of sexual attitudes a culture adopts profoundly affects the beliefs, lifestyles, and social perceptions of its adolescents.
Northwestern's School of Communication has been notably successful in producing a wealth of talented actors, playwrights, writers, and directors for film and television.

Among its distinguished alumni are Ann-Margret, Warren Beatty, Jodie Markell, Paul Lynde, David Schwimmer, Anne Dudek, Zach Braff, Zooey Deschanel, Marg Helgenberger, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Jerry Orbach, Jennifer Jones, Megan Mullally, John Cameron Mitchell, Dermot Mulroney, Charlton Heston, Richard Kind, Ana Gasteyer, Brad Hall, Shelley Long, and William Daniels.

The list also includes Cloris Leachman, Bonnie Bartlett, Paula Prentiss, Richard Benjamin, Laura Innes, Charles Busch, Stephanie March, Tony Roberts, Jeri Ryan, Kimberly Williams-Paisley, McLean Stevenson, Tony Randall, Charlotte Rae, Patricia Neal, Nancy Dussault, Robert Reed, Mara Brock Akil, Greg Berlanti, Bill Nuss, Dusty Kay, Dan Shor, Seth Meyers, Frank DeCaro, Zach Gilford, Nicole Sullivan, Stephen Colbert, Sandra Seacat, and Garry Marshall.
Esteemed directors Gerald Freedman, Stuart Hagmann, Marshall W. Mason, and Mary Zimmerman are also graduates.

Lee Phillip Bell, a talk show host in Chicago from 1952 to 1986, co-created the acclaimed soap operas "The Young and the Restless" in 1973 and "The Bold and the Beautiful" in 1987, which won Daytime Emmy Awards.
Broadway has seen successes from alumni such as Sheldon Harnick, Stephanie D'Abruzzo, Heather Headley, Kristen Schaal, Lily Rabe, Walter Kerr, and designer Bob Mackie.

The comedy theater Boom Chicago in Amsterdam was founded by Northwestern alumni, and the school is renowned for training future talent for The Second City, I.O., ComedySportz, Mad TV, and Saturday Night Live.
Tam Spiva contributed as a scriptwriter for "The Brady Bunch" and "Gentle Ben."
In cities like New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago, the impact of Northwestern alumni in theater, film, and television is so significant that some refer to it as a "Northwestern mafia."
The Empire was founded in 1336 by brothers Harihara I and Bukka Raya I of the Sangama Dynasty.
It gained prominence as the southern states attempted to fend off Islamic invasions by the late 13th century.
Named after its capital city, Vijayanagara, the empire's remnants surround modern-day Hampi, now a World Heritage Site in Karnataka, India.
The legacy of the empire includes numerous monuments across South India, with the most famous being those at Hampi.
The temple-building traditions of South India converged into the Vijayanagara Architecture style.
The diverse mix of faiths and local languages led to innovative Hindu temple designs in the Deccan and later in Dravidian styles, using local granite.

South Indian mathematics thrived under the empire's protection in Kerala, where the mathematician Madhava of Sangamagrama established the renowned Kerala school of astronomy and mathematics in the 14th century.
This school produced significant mathematicians such as Parameshvara, Nilakantha Somayaji, and Jyeṣṭhadeva during medieval South India.
Efficient governance and active overseas trade introduced new technologies like irrigation water management systems.
The empire's support allowed the fine arts and literature to flourish in Kannada, Telugu, Tamil, and Sanskrit, and helped evolve Carnatic music into its modern form.
The Vijayanagara Empire marked an era in South Indian history by transcending regional boundaries and promoting Hinduism as a unifying force.
It peaked under the reign of Sri Krishnadevaraya, with consistent military victories.
The empire expanded by annexing regions previously under northern Deccan Sultanates and eastern Deccan territories, including Kalinga, while retaining control over southern subordinates.
Many significant monuments were completed or commissioned during Krishna Deva Raya's rule.
Vijayanagara began to decline following its defeat in the Battle of Talikota in 1565.

Before forming Queen, Brian May and Roger Taylor were in a band called Smile. Freddie Mercury, originally named Farrokh "Freddie" Bulsara, was a fan of Smile and urged them to try more elaborate stage performances and recording techniques.
Mercury joined them in 1970, proposed "Queen" as the new band name, and took on his well-known stage name.
John Deacon joined the group before they recorded their self-titled debut album in 1973.

Although their first breakthrough in the UK charts came with their second album, Queen II, in 1974, it was the releases of Sheer Heart Attack later that year and A Night at the Opera in 1975 that truly brought them international fame.
The latter included "Bohemian Rhapsody," which topped the UK charts for nine weeks and popularized the music video format.
Their 1977 album, News of the World, featured "We Will Rock You" and "We Are the Champions," both of which became anthems at sports events.
By the early 1980s, Queen had become one of the world's biggest stadium rock bands.
Their performance at Live Aid in 1985 is considered one of rock history's greatest by many music publications, with a 2005 industry poll naming it the best.
In 1991, Mercury died of bronchopneumonia related to AIDS, and Deacon retired in 1997.
Since then, May and Taylor have occasionally performed together, including with Paul Rodgers from 2004 to 2009 and with Adam Lambert since 2011.
In November 2014, Queen released the album Queen Forever, featuring vocals from the late Mercury.
Compared to other team sports, the National Football League (NFL) preseason is highly structured.
Each NFL team typically plays four preseason exhibition games: two at home and two away.

However, two teams play a fifth game in the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These exhibition matches, mostly held in August, help coaches reduce the roster from 90 offseason players to the regular-season limit of 53.
Although the scheduling for preseason games is less rigid than the regular season, there are many restrictions and traditions that influence opponent selection and game timing.
Unlike baseball and hockey, where split-squad games are common, the NFL prohibits teams from splitting their roster to play two games in one day.
The NFL has hosted exhibition games in locations such as Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia, and Mexico to expand the league's global reach.
A game was once proposed for China but was canceled due to financial and logistical difficulties.
Playing against non-league teams is largely forbidden since the last such game occurred in 1972, and the last non-NFL opponent was the College All-Stars in 1976.
Many fans dislike exhibition games, as they are required to pay regular-season prices for them within season-ticket packages, leading to numerous, albeit unsuccessful, lawsuits against the NFL.
The Pro Bowl, considered an exhibition game, traditionally occurs after the season ends, though since 2011, it has been played the week before the Super Bowl.
The palace measures 108 meters (354 feet) in length by 120 meters (390 feet) in width, stands 24 meters (79 feet) tall, and offers over 77,000 square meters (830,000 square feet) of floor space.
This area is smaller than that of the Royal Palace of Madrid, the Papal Palace in Rome, the Louvre in Paris, the Hofburg Palace in Vienna, or the Forbidden City.
Inside, the palace boasts 775 rooms, with 19 state rooms, 52 main bedrooms, 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, and 78 bathrooms.
The main rooms are located on the piano nobile behind the west-facing garden façade at the rear of the building.
At the heart of this lavish suite of state rooms is the Music Room, notable for its large bow that dominates the façade.
The Music Room is flanked by the Blue and White Drawing Rooms. Centrally located in the suite is the Picture Gallery, a corridor that links the state rooms.
It is lit from above and stretches 55 yards (50 meters) long, featuring numerous works by artists like Rembrandt, van Dyck, Rubens, and Vermeer.
Additional rooms connected to the Picture Gallery include the Throne Room and the Green Drawing Room.
The Green Drawing Room serves as a large anteroom to the Throne Room and is part of the ceremonial path leading from the Guard Room at the top of the Grand Staircase.
The Guard Room is adorned with white marble statues of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert in Roman attire, set in a tribune lined with tapestries.
These formal rooms are reserved for ceremonial and official events but are open to the public each summer.
Madrasas, as Islamic higher learning institutions, were legally designated as waqf, charitable endowments, in central and eastern Islamic regions.
This designation allowed donors and their descendants to retain control, leading to a boom in establishing madrasas during the 11th and 12th centuries.
Conversely, in Western Islamic areas, the Maliki school's prohibition on donor control over endowments made madrasas less prevalent.
Unlike Western educational institutions with corporate status, the waqf model often excluded non-orthodox subjects like philosophy and natural sciences from madrasa curricula.
The Madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two remaining madrasas predating the earliest medieval universities, has been recognized as an official university only since 1947.

The other, al-Azhar, achieved university status through reforms in the 19th and 20th centuries, specifically in 1961, when it included secular subjects like economics, engineering, medicine, and agriculture in its curriculum.

Historically, many medieval universities functioned for centuries as Christian cathedral or monastic schools before formally becoming universitas scholarium, with their origins traceable to the 6th century AD, predating even the earliest madrasas.
Scholar George Makdisi, who has extensively studied this topic, concludes in his comparison between these two types of educational institutions:
Efforts to establish Hebrew as the national language for the Jewish people have struggled, as most Jews worldwide do not fluently speak it.

Instead, English has become the common language among the Jewish diaspora. While many Jews in the past were familiar enough with Hebrew to explore classical texts, and languages like Yiddish and Ladino were prevalently used as recently as the early 20th century, today most Jews lack proficiency in these languages, with English largely overtaking traditional Jewish dialects.
Currently, the top languages spoken by Jews are Hebrew, English, and Russian, with French and Spanish also widely used among some Jewish communities.
Historically, more Jews have spoken Yiddish than any other language, but its usage has declined significantly post-Holocaust, with Modern Hebrew’s adoption by the Zionist movement and Israel.
In some regions, the Jewish community's predominant language differs from that of the wider population.
For instance, in Quebec, the Ashkenazic majority speaks English, while the Sephardic minority primarily uses French.

Similarly, South African Jews have chosen English over Afrikaans. In Russia, both Czarist and Soviet policies shifted Jew's language from Yiddish to Russian, influencing neighboring communities as well.
Today, Russian is the primary language for many Jewish communities in post-Soviet areas like Ukraine, Uzbekistan, and for Ashkenazic Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan.

Though North African Jewish communities are currently small and shrinking, they transitioned from multilingualism to speaking predominantly French in Algeria, Morocco, and Tunis, whereas most North Africans continued using Arabic as their native language.
In "Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice," Terry Eastland discusses the primary justifications for affirmative action: correcting past discrimination and promoting diversity.
Eastland argues that affirmative action’s founders did not foresee how its benefits would predominantly aid those who do not truly need it, namely middle-class minorities.
She also believes that affirmative action perpetuates a stigma, fostering feelings of self-doubt and entitlement among minorities.
According to Eastland, these measures pose considerable risks and only occasionally yield positive outcomes.
She suggests that removing affirmative action would enable more open competition.
Libertarian economist Thomas Sowell echoes similar concerns in "Affirmative Action Around the World: An Empirical Study," where he highlights negative consequences of affirmative action.
Sowell claims such policies prompt non-preferred groups to identify themselves as members of preferred groups to benefit from preferential treatment.

He notes that affirmative action largely benefits the privileged members of preferred groups, like upper and middle-class blacks, while neglecting less fortunate individuals from non-preferred groups, such as impoverished whites or Asians.

Furthermore, Sowell argues that these policies decrease the incentives for both preferred and non-preferred groups to strive for excellence; the former because it’s unnecessary, and the latter because it seems pointless.
Ultimately, this leads to societal losses and breeds animosity towards preferred groups.
Van Praag asserts that the Ming court established diplomatic relations with Tibet primarily to secure much-needed horses.

Conversely, Wang and Nyima argue that these were not diplomatic missions at all, claiming that Tibetan regions were under Ming rule since Tibetan leaders held Ming official positions, and horses were collected from Tibet as a compulsory "corvée" tax, indicating Tibetans were handling domestic matters, not engaging in foreign diplomacy.

Sperling notes that the Ming simultaneously purchased horses in the Kham region while fighting Tibetan tribes in Amdo and receiving Tibetan embassies in Nanjing, contending that visits by Tibetan lamas to the Ming court primarily aimed to foster commercial exchanges between the lamas' affluent entourage and Ming merchants and officials.

Kolmaš mentions that while the Ming adopted a laissez-faire stance towards Tibet and limited the sizes of Tibetan retinues, Tibetans sought to maintain a tributary connection with the Ming, as imperial patronage afforded them wealth and influence.
Laird explains that Tibetans eagerly pursued invitations to the Ming court because the value of gifts they received for bringing tribute far exceeded that of the tribute itself.

Regarding the Yongle Emperor's gifts to his Tibetan and Nepalese vassals, including silver wares, Buddha relics, temple utensils, and monks' robes, Tsai notes that "in his effort to draw neighboring states to the Ming orbit so that he could bask in glory, the Yongle Emperor was quite willing to pay a small price."

The State Council Information Office of the PRC lists Tibetan tribute items as oxen, horses, camels, sheep, fur products, medicinal herbs, Tibetan incense, thangkas (painted scrolls), and handicrafts, with the Ming reciprocating with gifts of gold, silver, satin and brocade, bolts of cloth, grains, and tea leaves.
Ming silk workshops also catered to the Tibetan market with silk garments and furnishings adorned with Tibetan Buddhist designs.
Unlike the Spanish milled dollar, the U.S. dollar is structured on a decimal system.

The Coinage Act not only introduced the dollar but also established other monetary units: the mill, which is one-thousandth of a dollar (symbol ₥); the cent, or one-hundredth of a dollar (symbol ¢); the dime, or one-tenth of a dollar; and the eagle, or ten dollars. Each had specific weights and compositions of gold, silver, or copper.
In the mid-1800s, there was a proposal to name a hundred-dollar coin the "union," but no such coins were minted.
Patterns for the $50 "half union" do exist. Today, only the cent is commonly used as a subdivision of the dollar.

The term "dime" refers specifically to the 10¢ coin. "Eagle" and "mill" are largely unfamiliar, though mills are occasionally used in tax calculations, and fuel prices are often noted as $X.XX9 per gallon, such as $3.599, sometimes written as $3.599⁄10.

Currently, denominations less than a dollar are issued as U.S. coins, while those equal to or greater than a dollar are typically Federal Reserve notes, except for gold, silver, and platinum coins valued up to $100 as legal tender, though their bullion worth is much higher.
Both one-dollar coins and notes are produced today, with notes being more common.
Historically, "paper money" included denominations under a dollar (fractional currency), and gold coins were circulated with values up to $20 (the "double eagle"), discontinued in the 1930s.
The Coinage Act of 1792 introduced "eagle" as the term for a ten-dollar denomination, also used for naming gold coins.

Fractional currency was sometimes derogatorily called "shinplasters". In 1854, James Guthrie, the Secretary of the Treasury, suggested minting $100, $50, and $25 gold coins referred to as a "Union," "Half Union," and "Quarter Union," thereby suggesting a value of 1 Union = $100.

In 2012, Abigail Fisher, a student at Louisiana State University, and Rachel Multer Michalewicz, a law student at Southern Methodist University, filed a lawsuit against the University of Texas, challenging its admissions policy.
They claimed the policy was "race-conscious" and violated their civil and constitutional rights.
Texas's "Top Ten Percent Law" guarantees admission to any state public college or university for high school students graduating in the top ten percent of their class.
Fisher argued that her rejection from the University of Texas was based on her race, violating her 14th Amendment right to equal protection.

The Supreme Court heard the case on October 10, 2012, and issued a vague ruling in 2013, instructing the lower court to reconsider, asking the University to prove that achieving diversity couldn't be done through race-neutral means.
In July 2014, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit decided that the University of Texas could continue its "holistic" affirmative action approach.
On February 10, 2015, Fisher's lawyers brought the case back to the Supreme Court, contending that the Fifth Circuit was wrong both times.
The Supreme Court agreed in June 2015 to review the case again, with a decision expected by June 2016.
Athanasius shares his experience as a student under the tutelage of the Martyrs from the Great (tenth) and final persecution of Christians by pagan Rome.
[citation needed] This persecution was especially brutal in the East, notably in Egypt and Palestine.
Peter of Alexandria, the 17th archbishop there, was martyred in 311 as the persecution came to an end and might have been among his teachers.
Peter's successor, Alexander of Alexandria (312–328), was an Origenist and documented mentor of Athanasius.
As noted by Sozomen, Bishop Alexander "invited Athanasius to be his companion and secretary.
Athanasius was well-educated, proficient in grammar and rhetoric, and had already shown his wisdom and intelligence to those around him, even before rising to the episcopate."

Athanasius's earliest work, Against the Heathen – On the Incarnation (written before 319), reflects Origenist Alexandrian ideas, such as frequent references to Plato and using Aristotle's Organon definitions, albeit in an orthodox manner.

He was versed in various philosophical schools, particularly Neo-Platonism. Ultimately, Athanasius adjusted the School of Alexandria's philosophical stance away from purely allegorical interpretations characteristic of Origenist thought.
Yet, he continued to cite Homer in later works (Hist. Ar. 68, Orat. iv. 29). In his letter to Emperor Constantius, he defends himself with clear elements of Demosthenes' study, De Corona.
From the 8th to the 10th century, three dynasties vied for control of northern India: the Gurjara Pratiharas of Malwa, the Palas of Bengal, and the Rashtrakutas of the Deccan.
Eventually, the Sena dynasty took over the Pala Empire, while the Gurjara Pratiharas disintegrated into several Rajput states.
These Rajput kingdoms first appeared in Rajasthan in the 6th century, leading to small Rajput dynasties governing much of northern India.
Notably, a Gurjar Rajput from the Chauhan clan, Prithvi Raj Chauhan, became famous for his fierce battles against the advancing Turkic sultanates.
The Chola empire rose to prominence under Raja Raja Chola I and Rajendra Chola I, who successfully invaded regions of Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka in the 11th century.
Lalitaditya Muktapida (r. 724–760 CE) was an emperor of the Kashmiri Karkoṭa dynasty, which influenced northwestern India from 625 to 1003 CE and was succeeded by the Lohara dynasty.
He is renowned for his victories against Muslim and Tibetan expansions into regions controlled by Kashmir.
The historian Kalhana, in his *Rajatarangini*, credits Lalitaditya with leading an aggressive military campaign across Northern India and Central Asia.
He advanced into the Uttarapatha, defeating tribes such as the Kambojas, Tukharas (Turks in Turkmenistan and Tocharians in Badakhshan), Bhautas (Tibetans in Baltistan and Tibet), and Daradas (Dards).
His conquests continued as he subjugated the kingdoms of Pragjyotisha, Strirajya, and the Uttarakurus.
Meanwhile, the Shahi dynasty ruled parts of eastern Afghanistan, northern Pakistan, and Kashmir from the mid-7th to early 11th centuries.
Despite setbacks, the Luftwaffe was still capable of causing significant damage.
With Germany occupying Western Europe, Britain feared intensified submarine and air assaults on its sea routes.
Such an escalation could have grave implications for the war's outcome if the Germans prevailed.
Liverpool and its port became vital destinations for convoys from North America, carrying supplies and materials.

From there, a robust rail network distributed the goods across the country. The Liverpool Blitz proved successful for the attackers; air assaults sank 39,126 long tons (39,754 t) of shipping and damaged another 111,601 long tons (113,392 t).
Herbert Morrison, the Minister of Home Security, worried about a drop in morale, as civilians expressed defeatist attitudes.
Reports suggested that half of the port's 144 berths were unusable, and cargo unloading capabilities fell by 75%.
Roads and railways were blocked, and ships couldn't leave the harbor. On May 8, 1941, 57 ships were either destroyed, sunk, or damaged amounting to 80,000 long tons (81,000 t).
Approximately 66,000 homes were destroyed, leaving 77,000 people homeless, with 1,900 killed and 1,450 seriously injured in just one night.
Operations against London up until May 1941 threatened to impact morale severely.
In Hull, residents became "trekkers," fleeing the city before, during, and after attacks.
However, the bombardments failed to disable railways or port facilities for long, even in the frequently targeted Port of London, which handled one-third of overseas trade.
The 1998 season began on a somber note with the passing of legendary broadcaster Harry Caray.
With the retirement of Ryne Sandberg and the trade of Shawon Dunston, the Cubs faced gaps in their roster.
They signed Henry Rodríguez, fondly known as "H-Rod," to bat cleanup and provide lineup protection for Sammy Sosa, hitting 31 home runs in his first Chicago season.
Kevin Tapani led the team with a career-high 19 wins, Rod Beck anchored a strong bullpen, and Mark Grace delivered one of his finest seasons.
In 1998, the Cubs were under intense media scrutiny, with Sosa and rookie phenom Kerry Wood as the main attractions.
Wood’s standout moment was his one-hit performance against the Houston Astros, where he tied the major league record for 20 strikeouts in nine innings.
His incredible strikeout frequency earned him the nickname "Kid K" and the 1998 NL Rookie of the Year award. Sosa heated up in June, hitting a record 20 home runs for the month.
His home run rivalry with Cardinals slugger Mark McGwire quickly made them international superstars.
McGwire set a new major league record with 70 home runs by season's end, but Sosa’s .308 batting average and 66 homers earned him the National League MVP Award.

A tight Wild Card race with the San Francisco Giants concluded the regular season with a tie, forcing a one-game playoff at Wrigley Field, where third baseman Gary Gaetti hit the decisive home run, propelling the Cubs to the postseason with a 90–73 record.
However, their bats fell silent in October, as Jim Riggleman's squad batted only .183 and managed four runs, resulting in a sweep by Atlanta.

On a positive note, the thrilling home run chase involving Sosa, McGwire, and Ken Griffey Jr. attracted new fans to professional baseball and rekindled interest among those disenchanted by the 1994 strike.

The Cubs retained many players who had career years in ’98, but after a strong start in 1999, they faltered (beginning with a sweep by the cross-town White Sox in mid-June) and finished at the bottom of the division for the next two seasons.
After its release, *Evita* received critical acclaim. Zach Conner from *Time* magazine remarked, "It's a relief to say that *Evita* is impressive, well cast, and visually stunning.
Madonna surprises us once more. She portrays Evita with a touching weariness and undeniably possesses star quality.
Whether you love or hate Madonna-Eva, she draws everyone's attention." For her role, Madonna won a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture Musical or Comedy.
She released three singles from the *Evita* soundtrack, including "You Must Love Me," which won the Academy Award for Best Original Song in 1997, and "Don't Cry for Me Argentina."
Later, at the 1996 Billboard Music Awards, Tony Bennett presented Madonna with the Artist Achievement Award.
On October 14, 1996, Madonna gave birth to her daughter, Lourdes Maria Ciccone Leon, with Carlos Leon.

Biographer Mary Cross notes that although Madonna was often ill during filming and worried about her pregnancy affecting the film, she achieved significant personal milestones: "Now 38 years old, Madonna had finally succeeded on screen and realized her dream of having a child in the same year.
She reached a career turning point, reinventing herself and her public image." Her relationship with Leon concluded in May 1997, with her stating they were "better off as best friends."
After Lourdes' birth, Madonna became interested in Eastern mysticism and Kabbalah, introduced to Jewish mysticism by actress Sandra Bernhard in 1997.
Romantic relationships become more common during adolescence. By age 15, 53% of adolescents have experienced a romantic relationship lasting at least one month within the previous 18 months.
A 2008 YouGov survey for Channel 4 revealed that 20% of 14 to 17-year-olds in the UK had their first sexual experience at age 13 or younger.
According to a 2002 American study, the average age of first sexual intercourse was 17.0 for males and 17.3 for females aged 15–44.
As teens mature, the duration of their relationships tends to increase as well.

This trend can be attributed to sexual maturation and the development of cognitive skills needed to maintain romantic bonds, such as caregiving and attachment, although these skills are not fully developed until late adolescence.
Long-term relationships help adolescents cultivate the skills they need for high-quality relationships later on and foster a sense of self-worth.
Overall, positive adolescent romantic relationships can have long-term benefits.
High-quality romantic relationships are linked to greater commitment in early adulthood and positively impact self-esteem, self-confidence, and social competence.
For instance, adolescents with positive self-confidence often view themselves as successful partners, while negative experiences might lead to low confidence.
Adolescents generally date within their demographic based on factors like race, ethnicity, popularity, and physical attractiveness.

However, some traits, especially among girls, encourage seeking diversity. While most adolescents date peers close to their own age, boys usually date partners who are the same age or younger, whereas girls tend to date partners who are the same age or older.
During the second millennium BC, the area now known as Zhejiang was not heavily influenced by the Shang civilization.
It was inhabited by groups collectively called the Hundred Yue, including tribes like the Dongyue and Ouyue.
The kingdom of Yue first appeared in written records during the Spring and Autumn Period, with these chronicles placing it in northern Zhejiang.
The Shiji asserts that Yue's rulers were descendants of Shang's founder, Yu the Great.

Evidence indicates that the Baiyue and the kingdom of Yue had distinctive cultures and histories compared to those in northern and central China, whose pasts were well-documented during the Spring and Autumn Period and into the Qin dynasty.

One remarkable artifact from this era is "The Song of the Yue Boatman" (Chinese: 越人歌, pinyin: Yuèrén Gē, meaning "Song of the Man of Yue"), which was transliterated into Chinese around 528 BC by authors from Hebei and Henan.
This song reveals that the Yue people spoke a language unintelligible to those in northern China.
It appears the Yue also had their own written script, as evidenced by the Sword of Goujian inscribed with bird-worm seal script.
A notable figure from Yue was Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ, meaning "the Lady of Yue"), a renowned swordswoman. The state of Chu supported Yue to curb the expansion of the kingdom of Wu.
Under King Goujian, Yue rebounded from its early setbacks and fully annexed Wu's territories in 473 BC.
Subsequently, the Yue changed their capital from the area near Mount Kuaiji in present-day Shaoxing to Wu's former capital in present-day Suzhou.
With no southern adversaries remaining, Chu directly confronted Yue and successfully destroyed it in 333 BC.
Yue's former territories were absorbed by the Qin Empire in 222 BC and formed into a commandery named Kuaiji in Zhejiang, with its initial headquarters located in Wu in Jiangsu.
Microbiological culture is a key method for diagnosing infectious diseases. It involves providing a growth medium tailored for a specific microorganism.
A sample from potentially infected tissue or fluid is then tested for the presence of an infectious agent that can thrive in that medium.
Pathogenic bacteria generally grow well on nutrient agar, a type of solid medium that supplies the carbohydrates, proteins, and water essential for bacterial growth.
A single bacterium will proliferate into a visible mound on the plate's surface, known as a colony, which can either be isolated or merge into what is called a "lawn."
The colony's size, color, shape, and form are distinctive to the bacterial species, its strain, and the growth-supporting environment.
Additional ingredients are frequently incorporated into the plate to assist with identification.
These plates may contain substances that allow certain bacteria to grow over others or change color depending on the bacterial type.
Such bacteriological plates are standard in the clinical identification of infectious bacteria.
Microbial culture is also used to identify viruses, using a medium of cells grown in culture that the virus can infect, modify, or destroy.
For viruses, areas of dead cells from viral activity are known as "plaques." Similarly, eukaryotic parasites can be cultured for identification purposes.

Switzerland is located between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. The country comprises three main topographical regions: the Swiss Alps in the south, the Swiss Plateau (or Central Plateau) in the middle, and the Jura mountains to the west.
The Swiss Alps constitute a vast mountain range that spans the central-south area, covering roughly 60% of Switzerland's total land area. Most Swiss people reside in the Swiss Plateau.
The high valleys of the Alps are home to numerous glaciers, collectively covering an area of 1,063 square kilometers (410 sq mi).
These glaciers are the source of several important rivers, including the Rhine, Inn, Ticino, and Rhône, which flow in various directions across Europe.

Switzerland's hydrographic system includes some of the largest freshwater bodies in Central and Western Europe, such as Lake Geneva (also known as Lac Léman in French), Lake Constance (referred to as Bodensee in German), and Lake Maggiore.
Switzerland boasts over 1,500 lakes and holds 6% of Europe's freshwater reserves.
Overall, lakes and glaciers occupy about 6% of the country's territory. The largest lake, Lake Geneva, is located in western Switzerland and is shared with France.

The Rhône River is both the main inflow and outflow for Lake Geneva. Lake Constance is the second largest Swiss lake and serves as a midway point for the Rhine at the borders with Austria and Germany.

Although the Rhône flows into the Mediterranean Sea near the French Camargue region and the Rhine into the North Sea at Rotterdam in the Netherlands—almost 1,000 km apart—their springs are situated just 22 km apart within the Swiss Alps.

On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé tied the knot with Jay Z. She publicly announced their marriage through a video montage at the listening party for her third studio album, *I Am... Sasha Fierce*, held at Manhattan's Sony Club on October 22, 2008.
The album was released in the US on November 18, 2008, and introduced Beyoncé's alter ego, Sasha Fierce, which emerged during her 2003 hit single "Crazy in Love."
It sold 482,000 copies in its first week, debuting at number one on the Billboard 200, marking Beyoncé's third straight US number-one album.
The album included the number-one hit "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" and top-five hits "If I Were a Boy" and "Halo."
The success of "Halo" made it her longest-running Hot 100 single and helped her achieve more top-ten hits than any other female artist in the 2000s.
Additional hits from the album included "Sweet Dreams" alongside singles "Diva," "Ego," "Broken-Hearted Girl," and "Video Phone."
The music video for "Single Ladies" gained international fame, sparking what the Toronto Star called the "first major dance craze" of the Internet age.
The video won numerous awards, including Best Video at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the 2009 Scottish MOBO Awards, and the 2009 BET Awards.
At the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, it was nominated for nine awards, winning three, including Video of the Year.

However, its loss in the Best Female Video category to Taylor Swift's "You Belong with Me" led to Kanye West's infamous interruption and prompted Beyoncé to graciously share her acceptance speech time with Swift.
In March 2009, Beyoncé launched the I Am... World Tour, her second solo global tour, comprising 108 shows and grossing $119.5 million.
At the airport, many ground crew members are responsible for servicing aircraft.

A tow tractor positions the plane at one of the airbridges, and a ground power unit is connected to maintain electrical systems while the aircraft is stationary, since the engines, which generate electricity in flight, are off.
Passengers disembark via the airbridge, while mobile stairs may be used by the ground crew to access the cabin.
After landing, a cleaning service tidies the aircraft, and flight catering supplies food and beverages for the next flight.
A toilet waste truck removes waste from the onboard tanks, and a water truck refills the aircraft’s water supply.
Fuel transfer vehicles deliver aviation fuel from underground tanks to the aircraft.
Meanwhile, a tractor with dollies transports luggage between the terminal and aircraft.
When unloading, luggage is conveyed to the terminal, and hi-loaders lift heavy luggage containers to the cargo hold gate, where ground crew load them in.
After landing, these containers are placed on hi-loaders that lower them to the tarmac before transferring them onto dollies.
A conveyor truck handles any awkwardly shaped or late luggage. The airbridge is used again for new passengers to board.
The tow tractor then moves the aircraft from the terminal to a taxi area, aiming for a departure within 90 minutes. The airport charges the airline for the time the aircraft spends there.
Hidalgo is celebrated as the Father of the Nation, even though it was Agustin de Iturbide who actually secured Mexican Independence in 1821.
Following independence, the date to commemorate it fluctuated between September 16, marking Hidalgo's Grito, and September 27, when Iturbide triumphantly entered Mexico City to conclude the war.
Over time, political movements leaned towards the liberal Hidalgo rather than the conservative Iturbide, leading to September 16, 1810, being officially recognized as Mexican Independence Day.
Hidalgo is regarded as the "precursor and creator of the rest of the heroes of the Mexican War of Independence," symbolizing resistance against tyranny in Mexico.
His image appears in half a dozen murals by Diego Rivera and was portrayed with a flaming torch of liberty by José Clemente Orozco, who considered it among his finest works.
David Alfaro Siqueiros was commissioned by San Nicolas University in Morelia to create a mural for the 200th anniversary of Hidalgo's birth.
The town of his parish was renamed Dolores Hidalgo to honor him, and the state of Hidalgo was established in 1869.
Annually, on the night of September 15–16, the president of Mexico re-enacts the Grito from the National Palace balcony, a scene replicated by leaders across the country.
Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla's remains rest in the Angel of Independence column in Mexico City, alongside a lamp lit to symbolize the sacrifice of those who fought for Mexican Independence.
Presbyterian churches typically do not feature statues of saints or the elaborate altars common in Roman Catholic churches.
Instead, they have a "communion table" positioned at the same level as the congregation.

This table may be separated from the "Chancel" by a rail. The Chancel might contain a decorative, altar-like table, choir loft, choir stalls, lectern, and clergy area, and Presbyterians refer to the altar as the communion table and the altar area as the Chancel.
A Presbyterian church might display an altar cross, either on the communion table or a table within the Chancel.
The use of an "empty" cross, or cross of the resurrection, is intended to emphasize the resurrection, signifying that Christ died once and now lives eternally.
Many Presbyterian churches incorporate a cross encircled at the center, known as a Celtic cross, which underscores the resurrection and acknowledges the historical roots of Presbyterianism.

A baptismal font is typically located at the entrance or near the Chancel. Presbyterian architecture significantly incorporates symbolism, often featuring decorative stained glass windows illustrating biblical scenes.
Some churches may include ornate statues of Christ or detailed depictions of the Last Supper behind the Chancel.
For instance, St. Giles Cathedral, the Mother Church of the Church of Scotland, has a modern, faintly designed crucifix hanging next to one of the pulpits.

Of the 80 torch-bearers in London, Sir Steve Redgrave, who initiated the relay, revealed to the media that he had received emails urging him to boycott the event, adding that he understood their reasons for highlighting the issue.
Francesca Martinez and Richard Vaughan declined to carry the torch, while Konnie Huq chose to participate and also criticize China.
Pro-Tibetan Member of Parliament Norman Baker urged all bearers to reconsider their involvement.
Under pressure from various sides, Prime Minister Gordon Brown welcomed the torch outside 10 Downing Street but refrained from holding or touching it.
During the London relay, the BBC described the torch as being encircled by "a mobile protective ring."
Protests erupted as soon as Redgrave began the event, resulting in at least thirty-five arrests.
In Ladbroke Grove, a demonstrator briefly struggled with Huq in an attempt to seize the torch, and nearby, a fire extinguisher was discharged.
The Chinese ambassador carried the torch through Chinatown following an unannounced route change due to security concerns.
The torch was unexpectedly moved onto a bus along Fleet Street to avoid protesters amid security concerns.
In response to pro-Tibet demonstrations, over 2,000 Chinese supporters gathered along the torch route, displaying signs, banners, and Chinese flags to back the 2008 Beijing Olympics.
Many supporters concentrated in Trafalgar Square, showcasing the Olympic motto "One World, One Dream."
The album featured the hit single "Bohemian Rhapsody," which topped the UK charts for nine weeks.
Mercury's close friend and advisor, Capital London radio DJ Kenny Everett, played a key role in promoting the single.
It ranks as the third-best-selling single in UK history, exceeded only by Band Aid's "Do They Know It's Christmas?"
and Elton John's "Candle in the Wind 1997," and stands as the best-selling commercial single in the UK.
In the United States, it initially reached number nine, while a 1992 re-release climbed to number two on the Billboard Hot 100 for five weeks.
"Bohemian Rhapsody" is unique in selling a million copies on two separate occasions and became the Christmas number one twice in the UK, a feat unmatched by any other single.

Frequently voted the greatest song of all time, the band produced a groundbreaking music video to accompany the single, employing Trilion, a subsidiary of their former management company, Trident Studios, and using cutting-edge technology.
This video is widely considered the first "true" music video and helped popularize the medium.
The album's opening track, "Death on Two Legs," was reportedly written by Mercury about Norman Sheffield and the ex-management at Trident, who played a significant role in making the video popular.
Although bands like the Beatles previously made promotional films or videos for specific TV shows, "Bohemian Rhapsody" set a new standard.
As Rolling Stone notes, "Its influence cannot be overstated, practically inventing the music video seven years before MTV went on the air."
The album's second single, "You're My Best Friend," written by John Deacon, marked his first single and peaked at number sixteen in the United States, becoming a worldwide Top Ten hit.
The band embarked on the A Night at the Opera Tour in November 1975, covering Europe, the United States, Japan, and Australia.
Cellular metabolism and energy production rely on oxygen, but this can lead to the formation of potentially harmful compounds known as free radicals, which can cause mutations.
Most of these radicals are oxidizers that strongly react by accepting electrons.
For normal cellular maintenance, growth, and division, it is essential to neutralize these free radicals with antioxidants.
Recently, some researchers proposed an intriguing theory about the evolution of dietary antioxidants.

The human body produces some antioxidants like glutathione and Vitamin C but requires others through diet, such as Vitamin C in humans, Vitamin A, and Vitamin K. Some antioxidants can be synthesized by the body from other substances, like Beta-carotene, which is converted into Vitamin A, and Vitamin D, which is made from cholesterol through sunlight exposure.
Phytochemicals and their subset, polyphenols, form the majority of known antioxidants, totaling about 4,000.
These antioxidants work in a cooperative network, with some like Vitamin C reactivating free radical-containing compounds like glutathione or Vitamin E by taking on the radical itself.

Each antioxidant varies in its effectiveness against different free radicals, with some unable to neutralize certain types or function in specific areas—Vitamin A, being fat-soluble, protects fat regions, while Vitamin C, being water-soluble, guards watery areas.
When antioxidants interact with free radicals, they may produce new radical compounds that can be less or more harmful than the original.
A diverse array of antioxidants ensures that any resultant byproducts are efficiently handled, neutralizing the potential cascading effects of free radicals.
Zhejiang's key manufacturing sectors include electromechanical industries, textiles, chemicals, food, and construction materials.

The province has pursued a unique "Zhejiang model" of development. This model emphasizes entrepreneurship, supports small businesses that adapt quickly to market changes, invests heavily in infrastructure, and focuses on producing low-cost goods in bulk for both domestic use and export.
As a result, Zhejiang has become one of China's wealthiest provinces, and the "Zhejiang spirit" is celebrated nationwide.
However, some economists are concerned about the model’s sustainability, as it may be inefficient and overly reliant on raw materials and public utilities.
Moreover, the numerous small businesses focusing on low-cost production may struggle to transition to more advanced industries.
Economically, the focus in Zhejiang is shifting from North Zhejiang, centered on Hangzhou, to the southeast around Wenzhou and Taizhou.
In 2009, the per capita disposable income of urban residents was 24,611 yuan (US$3,603), with an annual real growth rate of 8.3%.
Rural residents had a per capita income of 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), growing 8.1% year-on-year.
In 2011, Zhejiang's nominal GDP reached 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion), with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490).

In 2009, the value of Zhejiang's primary, secondary, and tertiary industries was 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion), respectively.

Jehovah's Witnesses teach that the current era, referred to as the "system of things," entered the "last days" in 1914 and is soon to be destroyed through divine intervention by God and Jesus Christ, ensuring deliverance for true worshippers.

They view other contemporary religions as false, labeling them "Babylon the Great" or the "harlot" from Revelation 17, and believe these will be annihilated by the United Nations, the scarlet-colored wild beast of Revelation 17.

This event will signal the start of the "great tribulation." Afterward, Satan will assault Jehovah's Witnesses, triggering God's initiation of Armageddon, during which all governments and all individuals not identified as Christ's "sheep," or genuine followers, will be eliminated.
Following Armageddon, God's heavenly kingdom will encompass the earth, transforming it into a paradise akin to the Garden of Eden.
Most deceased individuals will be resurrected during a "judgment day" lasting one thousand years, judged by actions after resurrection rather than prior deeds.

After this period, Christ will return authority to God. A final test will occur when Satan is released to deceive perfect mankind; those who fail will be destroyed alongside Satan and his demons, culminating in a thoroughly tested and glorified humanity.

The Banner Armies of the Qing dynasty were structured based on ethnic lines, primarily consisting of Manchu and Mongol groups, but they also included non-Manchu bondservants registered under their Manchu masters' households.
As the Qing approached their conquest, the number of Han Chinese under Manchu rule grew significantly.
To address this, Hong Taiji established the Eight Han Banners. Around the time of the Qing's capture of Beijing, the Han Chinese numbers in these Banners rapidly increased.

In the early Qing period, particularly during the reigns of Shunzhi and Kangxi, Han Bannermen held significant status and power, often dominating positions such as Governor-Generalships and Governorships, overshadowing both Manchu Bannermen and Han civilians.
The Han outnumbered other groups within the Banners until the mid-18th century.
European visitors in Beijing referred to them as "Tartarized Chinese" or "Tartarified Chinese."
During Emperor Qianlong's reign, concerned about preserving Manchu identity, there was a renewed focus on Manchu ethnicity, ancestry, language, and culture within the Eight Banners.
This led to a large-scale removal of Han Bannermen, beginning in 1754, with many being asked to resign or having their names removed from the Banner rolls.
Consequently, the Banner system shifted from a Han majority to a Manchu majority.
Han garrisons in southern China, such as those in Fuzhou, Zhenjiang, and Guangzhou, were replaced by Manchu Bannermen.
The turnover severely affected provincial Han Banner garrisons but had less impact on those in Beijing, where a higher proportion of Han Bannermen remained.
From this period onward, the status of Han Bannermen diminished as Manchu Banners rose in prominence.

During Shunzhi's reign in 1648, 75% of Bannermen were Han, which dropped to 72% in 1723 during Yongzheng's reign, and further to 43% in 1796, at the start of Jiaqing's reign after Qianlong's purge, known as the Disbandment of the Han Banners.

Qianlong specifically targeted Han Bannermen descended from defectors who joined the Qing after they breached the Great Wall at Shanhai Pass in 1644, viewing them as traitors to the Ming and distrustful.

However, he retained those descended from defectors who joined the Qing prior to 1644 in Liaodong and participated in the passage through Shanhai Pass, who were known as those who "followed the Dragon through the pass."
According to earlier reports, in 632, following the death of Muhammad, several of his companions who had memorized the Quran were killed in a battle with Musaylimah.
In response, the first caliph, Abu Bakr (d. 634), decided to compile the Quran into a single volume for preservation.
Zayd ibn Thabit (d. 655), who wrote down divine revelations for Muhammad, took on the task of collecting the Quranic verses.
He, along with a group of scribes, meticulously compiled the verses into a manuscript.

This manuscript remained with Abu Bakr until his death. Zayd's challenges in gathering the Quranic material from parchments, palm-leaf stalks, stones, and the memories of men are detailed in early accounts.
After Abu Bakr's death, the manuscript was entrusted to Hafsa bint Umar, one of Muhammad's widows.

Around 650, the third Caliph, Uthman ibn Affan (d. 656), observed minor pronunciation differences in Quranic recitation as Islam spread beyond the Arabian Peninsula to Persia, the Levant, and North Africa.
To preserve the text's authenticity, he commissioned a committee led by Zayd to use Abu Bakr's copy to prepare an official version of the Quran.
Within two decades of Muhammad’s death, the Quran was thus formally documented.
This text served as the foundation for copies distributed across the Muslim world, with other versions reportedly destroyed.
Muslim scholars widely regard this version as the original Quran compiled by Abu Bakr.
Throughout his life and especially in the year following his death, many places were named after Tito.

However, several of these places have since reverted to their original names. For instance, Podgorica, once known as Titograd, returned to its original name, although its international airport still uses the airport code TGD.
Similarly, Užice, formerly Titovo Užice, changed back to its original name in 1992.
In Belgrade, the capital city, streets have been restored to their original pre–World War II and pre-communist names as well.
In 2004, a statue of Broz by Antun Augustinčić in his birthplace Kumrovec was damaged in an explosion, which decapitated it; it was later repaired.
In 2008, protests took place twice in Zagreb's Marshal Tito Square, organized by a group called Circle for the Square (Krug za Trg) to urge the city government to revert its name.
Meanwhile, a counter-protest by the Citizens' Initiative Against Ustašism (Građanska inicijativa protiv ustaštva) accused Circle for the Square of historical revisionism and neo-fascism.

Croatian President Stjepan Mesić criticized the push to change the name. In the Croatian coastal city of Opatija, the main street, which is also the longest, retains the name of Marshal Tito, as do many streets in northern Serbia.
In Sarajevo, one of the main streets is called Marshal Tito Street, and in the park in front of the university campus at Marijin Dvor, a statue of Tito remains a spot for people to honor him.
The world’s largest Tito monument, standing about 10 meters (33 feet) tall, is located at Tito Square in Velenje, Slovenia.

Additionally, a main bridge in Maribor, Slovenia's second-largest city, is known as Tito Bridge (Titov most), and in Koper, the largest Slovenian port city, the central square is also named Tito Square.
The northwestern region of Rajasthan is predominantly sandy and dry, largely dominated by the Thar Desert, which stretches into neighboring Pakistan.
The Aravalli Range runs parallel to the southwest monsoon winds coming from the Arabian Sea, preventing them from bringing moisture to this area, resulting in a rain shadow.
The Thar Desert is sparsely populated, with Jodhpur being its largest city and known as the gateway to the desert.
Significant districts within the desert include Jodhpur, Jaisalmer, Barmer, Bikaner, and Nagour.
This area is of strategic importance for defense, housing India's largest airbase in Jodhpur, along with military and BSF bases.

Jodhpur also hosts a civilian airport. Encircling the Thar Desert are the Northwestern thorn scrub forests, situated between the desert and the Aravallis. This region typically receives under 400 mm of rainfall annually.
