During their rule, the Mughal Empire and its tributaries were the dominant political forces, although eventually they faced challenges from emerging successor states like the Maratha Empire, which contested the progressively weakening Mughal dynasty.
Despite their often brutal methods of control, the Mughals succeeded by integrating with Indian culture—a strategy that distinguished them from the short-lived Sultanates of Delhi.
This era saw significant social changes as the Hindu majority came under the rule of Mughal emperors, who mostly displayed religious tolerance and actively supported Hindu culture.
Akbar, the notable emperor and grandson of Babar, aimed to foster good relations with Hindus.
In contrast, later emperors like Aurangzeb pursued complete Muslim dominance, leading to the destruction of historic temples and the imposition of taxes on non-Muslims.
Akbar had introduced "Amari," banning animal killings on holy Jain days, and abolished the jizya tax on non-Muslims.

Mughal emperors often married into local royalty, allied with regional maharajas, and blended their Turko-Persian culture with ancient Indian styles, giving rise to unique Indo-Saracenic architecture.

The erosion of these traditions, alongside increasing brutality and centralization, contributed significantly to the dynasty’s decline after Aurangzeb, whose policies departed from his predecessors' pluralism, provoking unrest among the predominantly Hindu population.
On June 20, 1794, Burke was honored with a vote of thanks from the Commons for his role in the Hastings Trial.
He then resigned, with his son Richard taking his place. Sadly, in August 1794, Burke suffered a devastating loss with Richard’s passing.
Burke was deeply attached to his son and saw great potential in him, which was not apparent to others, although Richard had played a successful part in the early fight for Catholic emancipation.
King George III, appreciating Burke’s stance on the French Revolution, wanted to make him Earl of Beaconsfield.
However, the possibility of this honor diminished with Richard’s death, leaving Burke only willing to accept a £2,500 pension.

The pension became the target of criticism from the Duke of Bedford and Earl of Lauderdale, prompting Burke’s well-known retort in his "Letter to a Noble Lord" (1796): "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform."

Burke insisted he was awarded based on merit, while the Duke of Bedford's rewards came solely from inheritance, highlighting that Burke's compensation was granted by a kind sovereign and Bedford’s ancestor from Henry VIII.
Burke also hinted at the consequences if their radical ideas were realized, providing an insightful view of the British constitution.
The complex ancestral history of Bermuda's population has been obscured over the last four centuries due to ethnic homogenization.
Today, there is virtually no ethnic distinction between black and white Bermudians, apart from those reflected in recent immigrant communities.

However, this was not the case in the 17th century. During the first hundred years of settlement, the majority consisted of white Protestants with English heritage, accompanied by smaller groups of Irish, who likely spoke Gaelic, and Scots, sent to Bermuda following English invasions after the English Civil War.

Non-white minorities included Spanish-speaking free (indentured) blacks from the West Indies, black slaves typically captured from Spanish and Portuguese ships by Bermudian privateers, and Native Americans from tribes along the Atlantic seaboard, and possibly as far as Mexico.
By the 19th century, the white, ethnically English Bermudians had lost their numerical dominance.

Although laws were enacted to ban Irish importation and efforts were made to force free blacks to emigrate and export black slaves, the blending of various minority groups, including some white English, led to the emergence of a new demographic termed "coloured."
In Bermuda, "coloured" referred to anyone not wholly of European ancestry, forming a slight majority.
Children born to one coloured and one white parent were categorized as coloured.
Most individuals historically labeled as "coloured" are now described as "black" or "of African heritage," which largely masks their non-African ancestry.

Individuals previously identified as "coloured" without African roots were few, though numbers of South Asians are now rising, evidenced by the doubling of those born in Asian countries between the 2000 and 2010 censuses.
Although blacks have remained the majority, this demographic has been balanced by new white immigration from Portugal, Britain, and other regions, countered by black immigration from the West Indies.
To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of rail fed from different feeder stations must remain thoroughly isolated.
This is accomplished through Neutral Sections, also called Phase Breaks, which are typically located at feeder stations and halfway between them.
Normally, only half of these sections are active, allowing another feeder station to be shut down as power is supplied from nearby feeder stations.

Neutral Sections consist of an earthed section of wire separated from live wires on either side by insulating materials, such as ceramic beads, enabling the pantograph to transition smoothly between sections.
The grounded section prevents arcing between live sections due to potentially high voltage differences when live sections exist on separate phases.
Protective circuit breakers might struggle to safely handle the significant current that could occur.
To avoid drawing an arc from one wire section to the ground while passing through the neutral section, trains must coast with circuit breakers open.
This is often done manually by drivers, who are aided by a warning board placed before the neutral section and an advance warning board some distance ahead.
Another board follows the neutral section, instructing drivers to close the circuit breaker, but only after the rear pantograph has passed it.

In the UK, an Automatic Power Control (APC) system manages the opening and closing of circuit breakers automatically using sets of permanent magnets along the track that interact with a detector on the train.
Despite this automation, drivers must still cut off power and coast, so warning boards remain in place near neutral sections and along their approach.
Since regaining independence, Estonia has positioned itself as a gateway between East and West, actively pursuing economic reform and integration with Western countries.

Its market reforms have made Estonia a leader among former COMECON nations.[citation needed] In 1994, inspired by Milton Friedman’s economic theories, Estonia implemented a flat tax, initially set at 26% for personal income, regardless of individual earnings.
The rate was lowered to 24% in January 2005, to 23% in January 2006, and further reduced to 21% by January 2008.
Estonia finalized its euro coin designs in late 2004 and adopted the euro as its currency on January 1, 2011, a delay caused by persistently high inflation.
Estonia also levies a Land Value Tax to fund local municipalities, setting the rate at the state level but allocating 100% of the revenue to local councils.

The local council determines the tax rate within a range of 0.1–2.5%. This tax, based solely on land value without considering buildings, is among the most critical funding sources for municipalities.

There are minimal exemptions, and even public institutions must pay the tax. Consequently, Estonia boasts a high rate of owner-occupied homes at about 90%, significantly higher than the 67.4% in the United States.
Fearing the worst, the Romans initiated a large-scale mobilization, nearly withdrawing from newly pacified Spain and Gaul.
They also established a significant garrison in Sicily in case the Seleucids reached Italy.
This fear resonated with Rome's Greek allies, who had mostly distanced themselves from Rome after the Second Macedonian War but now re-aligned with Rome for the first time since then.
A major Roman-Greek force was assembled under Scipio Africanus, the hero of the Second Punic War, and set off to Greece, marking the beginning of the Roman-Syrian War.
Initial clashes exposed serious Seleucid weaknesses, prompting them to attempt to replicate the Spartan defense at the Battle of Thermopylae.
However, like the Spartans, the Seleucids were defeated and forced to evacuate Greece.
The Romans pursued them across the Hellespont, marking the first entrance of a Roman army into Asia.
The decisive Battle of Magnesia ended in a complete Roman victory. The Seleucids sued for peace, compelled to relinquish their Greek conquests.
Although they still held extensive territory, this defeat signaled the decline of their empire, as they faced more aggressive foes to the east (the Parthians) and west (the Greeks).

Over the next century, their empire dwindled, overshadowed by Pontus. After Magnesia, Rome withdrew from Greece, assuming or hoping that the absence of a major Greek power would ensure lasting peace, but it resulted in the opposite.
In 1718, prompted by either Rector Samuel Andrew or Governor Gurdon Saltonstall, Cotton Mather reached out to Elihu Yale, a prosperous businessman living in Wales.
Born in Boston, Yale's father, David, was among New Haven's earliest settlers. Mather sought Yale’s financial assistance to construct a new building for the college.
Persuaded by Jeremiah Dummer, Yale, who had accumulated wealth through trade during his stay in Madras with the East India Company, contributed nine bales of goods.
These were sold for over £560, a considerable amount back then. In honor of Yale’s generosity, Mather proposed renaming the school to Yale College.
Concurrently, a Harvard alumnus in England convinced about 180 leading intellectuals to donate books to Yale.
The 1714 shipment, containing 500 volumes, represented the best of contemporary English literature, science, philosophy, and theology, significantly influencing Yale’s intellectual climate.
Undergraduate Jonathan Edwards encountered John Locke's works, which inspired his "new divinity" theology.
In 1722, the Rector and six friends, who formed a group to study these new ideas, renounced Calvinism, adopted Arminianism, and joined the Church of England.

They were ordained in England and returned as Anglican missionaries. Thomas Clapp became president in 1745 and attempted to steer the college back to Calvinist orthodoxy, though he left the library open. Some students discovered Deist literature there.
The Medieval Cholas emerged as a powerful dynasty in the mid-9th century C.E., creating the most significant empire South India had ever witnessed.
They unified South India and leveraged their naval prowess to extend their influence to Southeast Asian regions like Srivijaya.

Under rulers such as Rajaraja Chola I and his successors—Rajendra Chola I, Rajadhiraja Chola, Virarajendra Chola, and Kulothunga Chola I—the dynasty became an influential military, economic, and cultural force in South and Southeast Asia.
Rajendra Chola I's fleets sailed far, establishing control along sea coasts from Burma to Vietnam, the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, the Lakshadweep islands, Sumatra, and the Malay Peninsula.
The empire's might was showcased through Rajendra Chola I's expedition to the Ganges, the occupation of cities within Srivijaya, and multiple embassies to China.
The Cholas dominated Sri Lanka's politics for over two centuries through invasions and occupations and maintained robust trade with both Arab regions and the Chinese empire.
Rajaraja Chola I and his prominent son Rajendra Chola I achieved political cohesion across Southern India, solidifying the Chola Empire's status as a commanding sea power.
This era saw South India reach unparalleled levels in art, religion, and literature, with the Chola period representing the pinnacle of cultural movements initiated earlier by the Pallavas.
Their monumental temples and exquisite stone and bronze sculptures set new standards of excellence in India.
While Darwin was diligently working on his "big book" on Natural Selection, a parcel arrived on 18 June 1858 from Wallace, who was residing on the Maluku Islands (Ternate and Gilolo).

Inside were twenty pages outlining an evolutionary mechanism, sent in response to Darwin's recent encouragement, with a request to forward the document to Lyell if Darwin deemed it valuable. This mechanism was strikingly similar to Darwin’s own theory.

In a letter to Lyell, Darwin remarked that "your words have come true with a vengeance, ... forestalled," and stated he would "of course, at once write and offer to send [it] to any journal" Wallace preferred, adding that "all my originality, whatever it may amount to, will be smashed."
Lyell and Hooker proposed a joint presentation, combining Wallace's pages with excerpts from Darwin's 1844 Essay and his 1857 letter to Gray, to be submitted to the Linnean Society.

On 1 July 1858, the papers titled On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection, by Wallace and Darwin respectively, were read aloud but received little reaction.
Although Darwin viewed Wallace's idea as identical to his own concept of natural selection, historians have noted differences.
Darwin likened natural selection to artificial selection practiced by animal breeders, emphasizing individual competition.
In contrast, Wallace did not draw comparisons to selective breeding and focused on ecological pressures that maintained varieties adapted to local environments.
Some historians suggest Wallace may have been addressing group selection rather than individual variation.
Following the racially-motivated church shooting in Charleston, South Carolina, Yale faced renewed criticism in the summer of 2015 regarding Calhoun College, one of its 12 residential colleges.
Named after John C. Calhoun, a 19th-century slave owner and staunch supporter of slavery, the college’s name drew controversy.

In July 2015, students signed a petition demanding a name change, asserting that despite Calhoun's recognition as an "extraordinary American statesman" during his time, he was "one of the most prolific defenders of slavery and white supremacy" in U.S. history.
In August 2015, Yale President Peter Salovey addressed these racial tensions while speaking to the Freshman Class of 2019.

He explained why the college would retain its name, citing Calhoun as a "notable political theorist" and highlighting his roles as vice president to two U.S. presidents, a secretary of war and state, and a congressman and senator for South Carolina.
Salovey admitted Calhoun believed civilization depended on involuntary servitude and held that black people, whom he deemed inferior, should be subjected to slavery for their own benefit.
Racial tensions escalated in fall 2015 following comments by Nicholas A. Christakis and his wife Erika on free speech.
In April 2016, Salovey declared that despite long-standing protests from alumni and students, Calhoun's name would remain on the college.
He reasoned that Yale students should experience Calhoun's "shadow" to be "better equipped to face modern and future challenges."

Removing Calhoun's name, Salovey argued, would "obscure” his “legacy of slavery rather than confronting it," adding, "Yale is part of that history," and "We cannot erase American history, but we can confront, teach, and learn from it."
As a related change, the title "master" for faculty leading residential colleges will be changed to "head of college" due to its slavery-related connotation.

Windows 8's interface has received a mixed response from critics. Bright observed that the system's use of hot corners and edge swiping "wasn't very obvious," as the operating system provided minimal guidance on accessing functions through the user interface, even with the video tutorial included in the RTM release.
This tutorial only suggested that users point at screen corners or swipe its sides.

Despite this challenge, Bright mentioned that the interface worked well in certain aspects but became incoherent when transitioning between the "Metro" and desktop environments, sometimes using inconsistent methods.

Tom Warren of The Verge described the new interface as "stunning" and "surprising," noting that it created a "personal" experience once customized by users, though he acknowledged its steep learning curve and awkwardness when used with a keyboard and mouse.
Warren highlighted that while compelling all users to adopt the touch-focused interface was a risky strategy for Microsoft, it was essential for driving app development for the Windows Store.

Conversely, Adrian Kingsley-Hughes from ZDNet criticized the interface as "clumsy and impractical" due to its inconsistent design, likening it to "two operating systems unceremoniously bolted together."

He argued that "Windows 8 wasn't born out of necessity or demand; it was Microsoft's attempt to shape the PC industry toward touch and tablets, allowing competition against Apple's iPad and ensuring relevance."
At the Tokyo Game Show in September 2012, Sony announced the release of a new, slimmer PS3 redesign, model CECH-4000, set for late 2012.

This Super Slim model was offered with either a 250 GB or 500 GB hard drive. Three versions of the Super Slim were unveiled: one with a 500 GB hard drive, another with a 250 GB hard drive that was not available in PAL regions, and a third version with 12 GB flash storage exclusively available in PAL regions.
The 12 GB model could be upgraded with an official standalone 250 GB hard drive.
Additionally, a vertical stand was released for the model. In the UK, the 500 GB model was launched on September 28, 2012, followed by the 12 GB model on October 12, 2012.

In the US, the PS3 Super Slim debuted as bundled consoles, with the 250 GB model paired with the Game of the Year edition of Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception on September 25, 2012, and the 500 GB model bundled with Assassin's Creed III on October 30, 2012.
Japan received the black Super Slim model on October 4, 2012, and the white version on November 22, 2012.
The Super Slim model is 20% smaller and 25% lighter than the Slim model and features a manual sliding disc cover instead of the Slim model's motorized slot-loading cover.
The white Super Slim model was released in the US on January 27, 2013, as part of the Instant Game Collection Bundle. The Garnet Red and Azurite Blue models debuted in Japan on February 28, 2013.

In North America, the Garnet Red version was released on March 12, 2013, as part of the God of War: Ascension bundle, featuring 500 GB storage and including God of War: Ascension and the God of War Saga.
The Azurite Blue model was exclusively available at GameStop with 250 GB storage.
The Feinberg School of Medicine, formerly known as Northwestern University Medical School, has a legacy of notable graduates.

Among them is Mary Harris Thompson, Class of 1870, ad eundem, who became Chicago's first female surgeon, the first female surgeon at Cook County Hospital, and the founder of the Mary Thomson Hospital.
Roswell Park, Class of 1876, was a prominent surgeon who lent his name to the Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, New York.
Daniel Hale Williams, Class of 1883, was a trailblazer who performed the first successful American open-heart surgery and was the only Black charter member of the American College of Surgeons.

Charles Horace Mayo, Class of 1888, co-founded the Mayo Clinic. Carlos Montezuma, Class of 1889, was one of the first Native Americans to earn a Doctor of Medicine degree and established the Society of American Indians.
Howard T. Ricketts, Class of 1897, discovered the bacteria genus Rickettsia and uncovered the cause and transmission of Rocky Mountain spotted fever.
Allen B. Kanavel, Class of 1899, was the founder, regent, and president of the American College of Surgeons, recognized globally as a pioneer in modern hand and peripheral nerve surgery.
Nobel laureate Robert F. Furchgott, Class of 1940, won a 1996 Lasker Award and the 1998 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his co-discovery of nitric oxide.
Thomas E. Starzl, Class of 1952, made history with the first successful liver transplant in 1967 and earned the National Medal of Science in 2004 and a Lasker Award in 2012.
Joseph P. Kerwin, the first physician in space, participated in three Skylab missions and subsequently became director of Space and Life Sciences at NASA.
C. Richard Schlegel, Class of 1972, advanced the dominant patent for the HPV vaccine (marketed as Gardasil) to prevent cervical cancer.
David J. Skorton, Class of 1974, was a distinguished cardiologist who became president of Cornell University in 2006.
Andrew E. Senyei, Class of 1979, is known as an inventor, venture capitalist, and entrepreneur, founding several biotech and genetics companies and serving as a university trustee.
Boundaries can be seen as either inclusive or exclusive, depending on how others perceive them.
An exclusive boundary is created when someone adopts a marker that restricts the behavior of others.
Conversely, an inclusive boundary forms when a marker allows others to easily associate with it.
However, inclusive boundaries also impose restrictions by limiting individuals to one group, thereby excluding them from others.
For instance, if a newcomer in a multilingual room chooses to speak a particular language, some may understand it, while others may not.
Those who don't understand might view this choice simply as a neutral identity marker or as an exclusive boundary that separates them from the newcomer.
Conversely, those who do understand the language might see it as an inclusive boundary, connecting them with the newcomer while excluding others.
However, even among those who understand the language, some may prefer not to use it, viewing the newcomer's choice as an unwelcome imposition.
The newcomer might be aware or unaware of these dynamics, depending on whether she knows other languages or understands and respects the multilingual nature of the group.
During the 1980s, intense media fascination with the opinions and private lives of the royal family led to numerous sensationalized press stories, many of which were less than truthful.
Kelvin MacKenzie, then editor of The Sun, famously instructed his team: "Give me a Sunday for Monday splash on the Royals.
Don't worry if it's not true—so long as there's not too much fuss about it afterwards."

On September 21, 1986, newspaper editor Donald Trelford commented in The Observer: "The royal soap opera has now reached such a pitch of public interest that the boundary between fact and fiction has been lost ... not only do some papers avoid fact-checking or dismiss denials: they don’t care if the stories are true or not."
A notable report in The Sunday Times on July 20, 1986, claimed that the Queen was concerned about Margaret Thatcher's economic policies, which she feared encouraged social divisions.
The report also mentioned her alarm over high unemployment, civil unrest, violent miners' strikes, and Thatcher's refusal to enforce sanctions against apartheid in South Africa.
These rumors were reportedly sourced from royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal, though Shea insisted his comments were taken out of context and exaggerated.
Thatcher was rumored to have claimed that the Queen would vote for her political rivals, the Social Democratic Party.
According to Thatcher's biographer, John Campbell, "the report was a piece of journalistic mischief-making."
Contrary to reports of tension between Thatcher and the Queen, Thatcher later expressed her personal admiration for the monarch.
The Queen, in turn, awarded Thatcher two prestigious honors—membership in the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter—after she was succeeded by John Major as prime minister.
Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney described Elizabeth as a "behind the scenes force" in the abolition of apartheid.
In October 2014, a trial commenced for six senior staff and journalists from The Sun newspaper, who were charged with conspiracy to commit misconduct in a public office.
Among them was The Sun’s head of news, Chris Pharo, facing six charges. Former managing editor Graham Dudman and ex-deputy news editor Ben O'Driscoll each faced four charges.
Thames Valley district reporter Jamie Pyatt and picture editor John Edwards were charged with three counts, while ex-reporter John Troup was accused of two counts.

The trial centered on illegal payments allegedly made to public officials, with prosecutors claiming the group conspired to pay officials, including police, prison officers, and soldiers, from 2002 to 2011 to buy confidential information about the Royal Family, public figures, and prison inmates.
All the accused denied the charges. On January 16, 2015, Troup and Edwards were acquitted by the jury.
The jury partially cleared O'Driscoll and Dudman but continued deliberating on other charges against them, as well as those against Pharo and Pyatt.
On January 21, the jury informed the court they couldn't reach unanimous verdicts on the remaining charges.
Judge Richard Marks said he would accept majority verdicts shortly after one juror was discharged for health reasons.
The judge informed the remaining 11 jurors that he would accept verdicts of "11 to zero or 10 to 1."
On January 22, the jury was discharged after failing to reach verdicts on the outstanding charges, and the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) announced plans to seek a retrial.

The opening military maneuvers commenced in September 1806. In a notable letter to Marshal Soult outlining the campaign strategy, Napoleon detailed the key elements of Napoleonic warfare and introduced the concept of le bataillon-carré ('square battalion').
This system had the various corps of the Grande Armée advancing uniformly and maintaining close proximity.
This allowed for rapid support; if one corps was attacked, the others could swiftly come to its aid.
Napoleon invaded Prussia with 180,000 troops, advancing rapidly along the right bank of the River Saale.
As in earlier campaigns, his primary goal was to defeat one adversary before reinforcements from another could alter the war's outcome.
Upon discovering the Prussian army's location, the French shifted west and crossed the Saale with overwhelming force.
During the twin battles at Jena and Auerstedt on 14 October, the French decisively defeated the Prussians, causing significant casualties.
With several key commanders killed or incapacitated, the Prussian king failed to effectively lead the army, which began to unravel quickly.

In a pursuit celebrated as the "peak of Napoleonic warfare," according to historian Richard Brooks, the French captured 140,000 soldiers, over 2,000 cannons, and numerous ammunition wagons within a month.
Historian David Chandler remarked on the Prussian forces: "Never has the morale of any army been more completely shattered."
Despite their crushing defeat, the Prussians refused to enter negotiations with the French until Russia had a chance to join the conflict.

By the 1940s, the phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism had concluded. It became clear that statements about physical objects could not be converted into statements about actual and possible sensory data.
For a statement about physical objects to be translatable into one about sensory data, it must be at least deducible from the latter.
However, it was realized that we cannot derive even a single statement about physical objects from any finite set of statements describing actual and possible sensory data.
Remember that these translating or paraphrasing statements must involve normal observers in typical conditions.
Yet, no finite set of purely sensory statements can satisfy the requirement of having a normal observer present.
According to phenomenalism, claiming the presence of a normal observer is akin to hypothetically stating that if a doctor were to examine the observer, they would find the observer normal.

However, this doctor must also be a normal observer. To specify the doctor's normality in sensory terms, we would need a second doctor, who would have to experience the usual sensory data when examining the first doctor's sensory organs.
To further specify the second doctor as a normal observer using sensory terms, we must refer to a third doctor, continuing the cycle indefinitely (see also the third man problem).

Many insects have incredibly sensitive and specialized perception organs. Bees, for instance, can see ultraviolet light and detect polarized light, while male moths use their antennae to sense female moths' pheromones from kilometers away.
The yellow paper wasp (Polistes versicolor) communicates within its colony through distinctive wagging movements at a frequency of 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190).
These wagging signals indicate new material has arrived at the nest, and aggressive interactions among workers can encourage increased foraging activity.
Typically, insects exhibit a trade-off between visual acuity and chemical or tactile perception, with insects possessing well-developed eyes often having simplified antennae, and vice versa.
Insects perceive sound through various mechanisms, although these are not universally shared.
Generally, insects can hear sound if they produce it, albeit within a narrow range of frequencies typically tied to the sounds they generate.
For example, mosquitoes can hear up to 2 kHz, while some grasshoppers can hear as high as 50 kHz.
Certain predatory and parasitic insects recognize the characteristic sounds of their prey or hosts.
Some nocturnal moths can detect bats' ultrasonic emissions, aiding them in evading these predators.
Additionally, blood-feeding insects are equipped with sensory structures that detect infrared emissions, enabling them to locate their hosts.
As a young boy, Schwarzenegger was drawn to various sports, heavily influenced by his father.
His introduction to weightlifting came in 1960 when his soccer coach took the team to a local gym.

At 14, he made the pivotal decision to pursue bodybuilding over soccer. When asked if he began lifting weights at 13, Schwarzenegger clarified: "I actually started weight training at 15, but I'd been active in sports, like soccer, for years.
Though slim, I was well-developed enough to start gym workouts and Olympic lifting."
However, his official biography states: "At 14, he began intensive training with Dan Farmer, studied psychology at 15 to understand mind over body, and started his competitive career at 17."
In a 2001 speech, he recounted, "My plan formed when I was 14. My father wanted me to be a police officer like him, and my mother hoped I'd attend trade school."
Schwarzenegger frequented a gym in Graz and visited local theaters to watch bodybuilding idols like Reg Park, Steve Reeves, and Johnny Weissmuller on the big screen.
After Reeves' passing in 2000, Schwarzenegger fondly remarked: "As a teenager, I was inspired by Steve Reeves.
His achievements showed me what was possible when others didn't understand my dreams. Reeves has influenced everything I've achieved."
In 1961, he met former Mr. Austria Kurt Marnul, who invited him to train in Graz.
His dedication was such that he broke into the gym on weekends to continue his workouts.
"Missing a workout made me sick. I couldn't face myself in the mirror if I skipped it," he said.
Recalling his first movie experience, he added: "As a boy, I remember my father taking me to Austrian theaters to see newsreels. The first real movie I recall was a John Wayne film."

The doctrine of Mary's Immaculate Conception emerged later among Latin theologians, especially the Franks, but found clearer expression among Byzantine theologians with roots in Gregory Nazianzen's Mariology during the Medieval Byzantine era.
Poets and scholars, including Emperor Justinian I, often referred to Mary as "prepurified" in their writings and creeds.
Sophronius of Jerusalem offered a pivotal interpretation of Nazianzen's ideas, explaining that Mary was already immaculate at the time of the Annunciation.
He even suggested that John the Baptist was "holier than all 'Men' born of woman," acknowledging that Mary's extraordinary holiness eclipsed even John's, who was sanctified in utero.

Sophronius' teachings were further developed by St. John Damascene (d. 749/750), who praised Mary for her purification at the Annunciation and uniquely recognized her role in "purifying the waters of baptism by touching them," an honor traditionally reserved for Christ, according to Nazianzen's legacy.
Damascene elaborated on the parallel holiness between Mary's prepurification and Jesus' purification in the New Testament, likening her holiness at the Annunciation to Christ's baptism at the Jordan.
His hymns and the work "De fide Orthodoxa" utilized Mary's "pre purification" to emphasize her unparalleled holiness and pure human nature.

Damascene, along with Nazianzen, influenced nearly all later depictions of Mary's complete holiness, stemming from her conception by the "all pure seed" of Joachim and the womb of St. Ann, which is metaphorically described as "wider than heaven."
On April 9, the North American leg of the torch relay took place in San Francisco, California.

That day, officials rerouted the torch to an undisclosed path. The relay began at McCovey Cove, where Norman Bellingham of the U.S. Olympic Committee handed the torch to Lin Li, the Chinese swimmer and 1992 Olympic champion.
The anticipated closing ceremony at Justin Herman Plaza was cancelled, replaced by an event at San Francisco International Airport as the torch departed for Buenos Aires.
The route adjustment aimed to sidestep large crowds of both supporters of China and protesters.
The sudden change sparked anger among some who had gathered at Justin Herman Plaza; one demonstrator claimed the reroute was intended to "thwart any organized protest."

Aaron Peskin, President of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors and critic of Mayor Gavin Newsom, described the changes as a "cynical plan" to satisfy the Bush administration and the Chinese government, pointing to "the incredible influence of money."
In contrast, Newsom argued the move was in "everyone's best interest" and maintained that people retained their right to protest and support the torch despite the revised route.
Peter Ueberroth, head of the U.S. Olympic Committee, praised the changes, stating, "The city of San Francisco, from a global perspective, will be applauded."
Spectators who managed to see the torch expressed surprise and joy, as evident in live video footage from CBS and NBC.
The city's cost for hosting the event was reported at $726,400, with nearly half offset by private fundraising.
Mayor Newsom noted that the route change, made in consultation with Police Chief Heather Fong, avoided "exponential" expenses related to potential mass arrests.

The current family of Mac products utilizes Intel x86-64 processors. During the shift from PowerPC chips, Apple introduced an emulator named Rosetta, similar to the one used a decade earlier when transitioning from Motorola 68000 architecture.
The Macintosh remains the sole mainstream computer platform to have successfully switched CPU architectures twice.
Most new Mac models come standard with at least 8 GB of RAM, except for the 1.4 GHz Mac Mini, MacBook Pro (without Retina Display), and MacBook Air.
Today's Mac computers feature ATI Radeon or nVidia GeForce graphics cards and integrated Intel graphics within the CPU.
All current Macs, with the exception of the MacBook Pro without Retina Display, don't have an optical media drive for dual-function DVD/CD burning, known as a SuperDrive.
The latest Macs include two standard data transfer ports: USB and Thunderbolt, except for the 2015 MacBook version which only features a USB-C port and a headphone port.
MacBook Pro, iMac, MacBook Air, and Mac Mini models are now equipped with the Thunderbolt port, which Apple claims can transfer data at speeds reaching 10 gigabits per second.
USB became standard with the 1998 iMac G3 and is widespread today, whereas FireWire is primarily used for high-performance devices like hard drives or video cameras.

Beginning with the iMac G5, released in October 2005, Apple included built-in iSight cameras on suitable models and a media center interface called Front Row, operable via an Apple Remote or keyboard for media stored on the computer.
However, Front Row was discontinued in 2011, and the Apple Remote is no longer provided with new Macs.
As expected by Nimitz, the Japanese fleet arrived near Midway on June 4, where it was detected by PBY patrol aircraft.
Nagumo launched an initial attack against Midway, while Fletcher deployed his aircraft targeting Nagumo's carriers.

The first U.S. carrier aircraft to reach the scene were TBD Devastator torpedo bombers from Hornet at 09:20, but their assaults were poorly coordinated and ineffective; partially due to faulty aerial torpedoes, they did not land a single hit, and all 15 were shot down by defending Zero fighters.
At 09:35, 15 more TBDs from Enterprise attacked, with 14 lost and again no hits achieved.

Though Fletcher's attacks seemed disorganized and largely ineffective, they managed to lure Nagumo's defensive fighters down to sea level, where they used up much of their fuel and ammunition repelling the two waves of torpedo bombers.
Consequently, when U.S. dive bombers arrived at high altitude, the Zeros were ill-positioned to defend.
Furthermore, Nagumo's four carriers had drifted out of formation while evading torpedoes, diminishing their concentration of anti-aircraft fire.
Nagumo's indecision added to the confusion on his carriers as he contemplated a second strike on Midway while being aware of American carriers nearby.
Twice, he altered the arming orders for his aircraft, leading the American dive bombers to find the Japanese carriers cluttered with munitions as crews hurried to properly re-arm their air groups.
Scotland remained an independent kingdom until 1603, when the King of Scotland inherited the crowns of both England and Ireland.
The following century was marked by political unrest, religious division, and warfare.
English colonialism, which began in Ireland in the 16th century, expanded with the establishment of large Scottish and English colonies in Ulster.
Tensions rose, especially as the English king's policy of tolerance towards Catholicism clashed with Parliament.
This discord led to the English Civil War, also known as the War of the Three Kingdoms, resulting in a revolutionary republic.

Although predominantly Catholic Ireland mostly supported the king, defeat by Parliament's army led to significant land redistribution from loyalist Irish nobility to English commoners serving in the parliamentary forces.
This shift began the rise of a new "Ascendancy" class that, over the next hundred years, replaced the English (Hiberno-Norman) and Gaelic Irish nobility.
This new ruling class, Protestant and British, contrasted with the largely Catholic and Irish populace, influencing Irish politics for centuries.
When the English monarchy was restored, the king could not politically restore the lands of former Irish landowners.
The "Glorious Revolution" of 1688 echoed these themes, with a Catholic king advocating for religious tolerance against a Protestant Parliament.
The king's army was defeated in Ireland at the Battle of the Boyne and the crucial Battle of Aughrim.
Despite resistance and a pledge for religious tolerance in the Treaty of Limerick, its terms were later overridden in the shifting political landscape.
A new monarchy emerged, and the Irish parliament, now dominated by the new elite, enacted increasingly oppressive Penal Laws affecting both Dissenters and Catholics.
Digestion occurs in different phases: the cephalic, gastric, and intestinal phases.
The cephalic phase begins with the sight, thought, and smell of food, which stimulate the cerebral cortex.

These stimuli are sent to the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata, then routed through the vagus nerve, leading to the release of acetylcholine. During this phase, gastric secretion reaches 40% of its maximum rate.
Since the acidity in the stomach isn't buffered by food, it inhibits the activity of parietal cells (which secrete acid) and G cells (which secrete gastrin) via D cell secretion of somatostatin.
The gastric phase lasts 3 to 4 hours and is triggered by the stomach's distension, the presence of food, and decreased pH.
Distention activates long and myenteric reflexes, releasing acetylcholine and stimulating more gastric juice production.
As proteins enter the stomach, they bind with hydrogen ions, increasing the pH and lifting the inhibition on gastrin and gastric acid secretion.
This causes G cells to release gastrin, prompting parietal cells to secrete gastric acid, which consists of about 0.5% hydrochloric acid (HCl), lowering the pH to 1-3.
Acetylcholine and histamine also trigger acid release. The intestinal phase has two parts: excitatory and inhibitory.
Partially digested food enters the duodenum, triggering the release of intestinal gastrin.
The enterogastric reflex inhibits the vagal nuclei, activates sympathetic fibers which tighten the pyloric sphincter to prevent more food from entering, and inhibits local reflexes.
In the late 1980s, Libya introduced a series of economic reforms to address declining oil revenues.
In May 1987, Gaddafi launched the "Revolution within a Revolution," focusing on industrial and agricultural reforms and the revival of small businesses.
The Revolutionary Committees faced restrictions; in March 1988, a new Ministry for Mass Mobilization and Revolutionary Leadership limited their violent and judicial activities.
In August 1988, Gaddafi criticized these committees, stating they had "deviated, harmed, tortured" and insisted that "true revolutionaries do not practice repression."
That March, hundreds of political prisoners were released, although Gaddafi inaccurately claimed there were none left in Libya.

In June, the government published the Great Green Charter on Human Rights in the Era of the Masses, outlining 27 articles to improve human rights, limit the death penalty, and call for its eventual abolition.
While some measures in the charter were implemented the following year, others were not.

Additionally, in 1989, the government established the Al-Gaddafi International Prize for Human Rights, honoring Third World figures who opposed colonialism and imperialism, with Nelson Mandela as the first recipient.
Between 1994 and 1997, the government formed cleansing committees to combat corruption, especially in the economic sector.
In 1938, the Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS), originally established by the Columbia Phonograph Company but later sold, acquired ARC and renamed it the Columbia Recording Corporation.
Although the Columbia Phonograph Company once had international branches like the Columbia Graphophone Company in the UK, these were sold before CBS purchased American Columbia.
Ted Wallerstein, an executive from RCA Victor Records, persuaded CBS head William S. Paley to acquire ARC.
After the acquisition, Paley appointed Wallerstein as the head of the new record company.
Under the new structure, Columbia became the primary label with Okeh as a subsidiary, while ARC's lesser labels were downplayed.
Consequently, ARC’s leased labels, Brunswick Records and Vocalion Records, reverted to previous owner Warner Bros., who then sold them to Decca Records.
Columbia retained the rights to the Brunswick catalog recorded from December 1931 onward, which was reissued under the Columbia label, along with Vocalion material reissued under the Okeh label.

Wallerstein, promoted from president to chairman of the record company in late 1947, restored Columbia to prominence and led the successful launch of the long-playing (LP) record before retiring as chairman in 1951.

James Conkling subsequently took over as head of Columbia Records. That year, Columbia ended its relationship with the EMI-owned label of the same name and initiated a UK distribution agreement with Philips Records, while Okeh Records continued to be distributed by EMI under the Columbia label.
Yale University has produced distinguished alumni across diverse fields. Notable figures include U.S. Presidents William Howard Taft, Gerald Ford, George H. W. Bush, Bill Clinton, and George W. Bush.
Among royalty, Yale counts Crown Princess Victoria Bernadotte, Prince Rostislav Romanov, and Prince Akiiki Hosea Nyabongo.

Prominent heads of state include Italian Prime Minister Mario Monti, Turkish Prime Minister Tansu Çiller, Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo, German President Karl Carstens, and Philippine President José Paciano Laurel.
U.S. Supreme Court Justices from Yale comprise Sonia Sotomayor, Samuel Alito, and Clarence Thomas.
Noteworthy U.S. Secretaries of State include John Kerry, Hillary Clinton, Cyrus Vance, and Dean Acheson.
Literary talents like authors Sinclair Lewis, Stephen Vincent Benét, and Tom Wolfe, and lexicographer Noah Webster are among Yale's graduates.
Inventive minds such as Samuel F. B. Morse and Eli Whitney, along with patriot Nathan Hale and theologian Jonathan Edwards, also hail from Yale.
In the arts, alumni range from actors and directors like Paul Newman, Meryl Streep, and Oliver Stone, to composers such as Charles Ives and Cole Porter.
Yale also has left its mark in sports with figures like Walter Camp, Ron Darling, and Chris Dudley.
Influential architects Eero Saarinen and Norman Foster, sculptor Richard Serra, and film critic Gene Siskel also studied there.
Yale's contributions extend to journalism with commentators Dick Cavett and Anderson Cooper, journalist David Gonzalez, and pundits like William F. Buckley Jr. and Fareed Zakaria.
Economists and scientists like Paul Krugman, Ernest Lawrence, and Francis S. Collins further highlight Yale's impact.
In business, alumni include Henry Luce, Harold Stanley, and FedEx founder Frederick W. Smith.
Pioneer Austin Cornelius Dunham exemplifies Yale's reach in electrical innovation.
The "Bleacher Bums" is a nickname for fans who often spend their day heckling in the bleacher section at Wrigley Field.
Originally called "bums," the term was used for fans who were present at most games, which, being daytime events, suggested they were not employed.
Many of these fans are, or were, students from Chicago area universities like DePaul, Loyola, Northwestern, and Illinois-Chicago.
This group inspired a Broadway play featuring Joe Mantegna, Dennis Farina, Dennis Franz, and James Belushi, centered around Cub fans regularly attending the games.
The group was established in 1967 by enthusiastic fans Ron Grousl, Tom Nall, and "mad bugler" Mike Murphy, a sports radio host on WSCR AM 670 "The Score."
Murphy claims Grousl initiated the tradition of throwing back home run balls hit by opposing teams at Wrigley.

Derek Schaul, known as Derek the Five Dollar Kid, currently leads the group. Before the 2006 season, updates were made with new shops and a private bar, The Batter's Eye, added, and Bud Light secured naming rights, calling it the Bud Light Bleachers.
At Wrigley, bleacher seats are generally admission only, except during the playoffs.

The bleachers are known as the "World's Largest Beer Garden." A popular T-shirt sold inside the park, licensed by the club, promotes this stereotype with the front saying "Wrigley Bleachers" and the back reading "Shut Up and Drink Your Beer."
In 1824, French physicist François Arago introduced the concept of rotating magnetic fields, known as Arago's rotations.
This idea led to the creation of the first primitive induction motor in 1879 when Walter Baily manually switched it on and off.
Throughout the 1880s, inventors aimed to develop AC motors, as AC was beneficial for long-distance, high-voltage transmission but lacked operable motors.
Galileo Ferraris and Nikola Tesla independently invented the first AC commutatorless induction motors, with Ferraris presenting a working model in 1885 and Tesla in 1887.
In 1888, the Royal Academy of Science of Turin published Ferraris' research on motor operation but doubted its commercial potential.

Meanwhile, Tesla presented a paper to the AIEE describing three types of two-phase, four-stator-pole motors: a non-self-starting reluctance motor, a self-starting induction motor with a wound rotor, and a synchronous motor with a separately excited DC rotor winding.
One of Tesla's patents from 1887 also detailed a shorted-winding-rotor induction motor.
George Westinghouse quickly purchased Tesla’s patents, hired him to develop them, and enlisted C. F. Scott to assist, although Tesla left in 1889.
While constant-speed AC induction motors were unsuitable for streetcars, Westinghouse successfully powered a Telluride, Colorado mining operation in 1891.

Committed to three-phase development, Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky invented the three-phase cage-rotor induction motor in 1889 and the three-limb transformer in 1890, which are now standard in commercial applications.
Despite Dolivo-Dobrovolsky's claims of impracticality due to two-phase pulsations, Westinghouse developed its first practical induction motor in 1892, followed by a line of polyphase motors in 1893.
These were initially two-phase motors with wound rotors, until B.G. Lamme's rotating bar winding rotor design emerged.

The General Electric Company began developing three-phase induction motors in 1891, and by 1896, they signed a cross-licensing agreement with Westinghouse for the bar-winding-rotor design, later known as the squirrel-cage rotor.
These advancements and innovations have led to modern 100 horsepower (HP) induction motors sharing the same mounting dimensions as a 7.5 HP motor from 1897.
Umayyad mosaics, particularly non-religious ones, predominantly adorned the floors of caliphs' palaces and those of other high-ranking officials.
These mosaics took heavy inspiration from the Roman country villas once prevalent in the Eastern Mediterranean.
The most outstanding example is found in the bathhouse of Hisham's Palace in Palestine, created around 744.
This main panel illustrates a large tree with a lion attacking a deer on the right side, while two deer graze peacefully on the left, likely symbolizing the themes of good versus bad governance.
In the 8th-century Umayyad palace complex at Anjar, Lebanon, mosaics featuring classical geometric patterns have been preserved in the bath area.
Al-Walid II's luxurious desert residence in Qasr al-Hallabat, now in Jordan, was similarly adorned with highly skilled floor mosaics.
The best-preserved panel at Hallabat features a Tree of Life divided among "good" and "bad" animals.
The mosaics at Hallabat also include vine scrolls, grapes, pomegranates, oryx, wolves, hares, leopards, pairs of partridges, fish, bulls, ostriches, rabbits, rams, goats, lions, and a snake.
Excavations in 2000 at Qastal, near Amman, uncovered the earliest known Umayyad mosaics in modern Jordan, likely dating from 685–705 during Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan's rule.
These mosaics, likely part of a local governor's palace, feature geometric patterns, trees, animals, fruits, and rosettes, covering all but the open courtyard, entrance, and staircases.
In 1855, the state rallied behind the Plan of Ayutla and approved the new constitution.
During the Reform War, it endured with little damage, thanks to its many liberal political figures.
The 1858 conservative movement failed in the state, even after the conservative leader Zuloaga successfully occupied the cities of Chihuahua and Parral with 1,000 men.
In August 1859, Zuloaga and his forces were defeated by the liberal leader Orozco, who then briefly deposed the state governor before fleeing to Durango two months later.
In the late 1860s, conservative General Cajen entered the state following his campaign through Jalisco.
He helped install conservative politicians and ousted liberal leaders Jesús González Ortega and José María Patoni.
Cajen took control of the state capital, declared himself governor, and swiftly assembled a large force, defeating the liberals in La Batalla del Gallo.
Despite his initial success, Cajen soon lost power due to a strong liberal resurgence.
Liberal leaders José María Patoni of Durango and J.E. Muñoz of Chihuahua regained influence by limiting the clergy's political rights according to a presidential decree.
The state elected General Luis Terrazas, a liberal, as governor. He continued to combat small conservative uprisings throughout 1861.
In 1878, with the assistance of vacuum pump expert Charles Stearn, Swan developed a method to prevent early bulb blackening, earning a British Patent in 1880.
On December 18, 1878, he displayed a lamp with a slender carbon rod at a Newcastle Chemical Society meeting, followed by a working demonstration on January 17, 1879.
The lamp was also showcased to 700 visitors at a meeting of the Literary and Philosophical Society of Newcastle upon Tyne on February 3, 1879.
These lamps employed a carbon rod typical of arc lamps, rather than a slender filament, resulting in low resistance and requiring large conductors for sufficient current.
While not commercially viable, they demonstrated the potential for incandescent lighting using a high vacuum, carbon conductor, and platinum lead-in wires.
However, due to the excessive current requirement and short lifespan, Swan shifted focus to improving the carbon filament and its attachment technique.
He pioneered a method using cotton to produce 'parchmentised thread' and secured British Patent 4933 in 1880.
That year, Swan began to install light bulbs in homes and landmarks across England, including his own house, which became the first in the world lit by a lightbulb and by hydroelectric power.
In 1878, Lord Armstrong's home at Cragside was also among the first to be electrified. By the early 1880s, Swan had founded his own company.
In 1881, Swan's incandescent lightbulbs illuminated the Savoy Theatre in Westminster, London, marking it as the first theatre, and public building globally, to be exclusively lit by electricity.
On March 13, the upper Clyde port of Clydebank near Glasgow was bombed, leaving only seven out of its 12,000 houses intact.
Numerous other ports were attacked, with Plymouth suffering five assaults by month's end, while Belfast, Hull, and Cardiff were also targeted.
Cardiff endured bombings on three separate nights, and Portsmouth's center was ravaged by five raids.
By September 1940, civilian housing loss was at a rate of 40,000 people dehoused per week.

In March 1941, two raids on Plymouth and London displaced 148,000 individuals. Despite severe damage, British ports continued supporting war efforts, facilitating supplies from North America, and the Royal Navy maintained operations in Plymouth, Southampton, and Portsmouth.
Plymouth, situated vulnerably on the south coast near German air bases, encountered the most intense attacks.

On March 10-11, 240 bombers dropped 193 tons of high explosives and 46,000 incendiaries, severely damaging residential and commercial areas and disrupting electricity, with five oil tanks and two magazines detonating.

Nine days later, another fierce assault saw two waves of 125 and 170 bombers release 160 tons of high explosives and 32,000 incendiaries, devastating much of the city center and impacting port facilities, although many bombs struck the city itself.
On April 17, 250 bombers led by KG 26 dropped 346 tons of explosives and 46,000 incendiaries, causing significant damage and deploying aerial mines.
Over 2,000 anti-aircraft shells fired hit two Ju 88 aircraft. By the air campaign's conclusion over Britain, only eight percent of German attacks on British ports employed mines.
The first Ottoman Medrese was established in İznik in 1331, and most Ottoman medreses adhered to the traditions of Sunni Islam.
When an Ottoman sultan founded a new medrese, he would invite scholars from across the Islamic world.
For instance, Murad II brought in scholars from Persia, such as ʻAlāʼ al-Dīn and Fakhr al-Dīn, to enhance the medrese’s reputation.
This demonstrates the interconnectedness of the Islamic world during the early modern period, as scholars traveled between Islamic states to exchange knowledge.

Hamadeh notes that this globalization indicated the Ottoman Empire's modernization, stating: “Change in the eighteenth century as the beginning of a long and unilinear march toward westernisation reflects the two centuries of reformation in sovereign identity.” İnalcık also mentions that Ottomans traveled abroad to places like Egypt, Persia, and Turkestan to further their education, illustrating the reciprocity of knowledge exchange.
Much like today, individuals traveled internationally to learn and share knowledge, suggesting the world was more interconnected than it might appear.

This parallels modern systems where students study abroad. An example of Ottoman madaris includes those built by Mehmed the Conqueror, who constructed eight madaris on each side of a mosque—eight for specialized studies and eight for preparatory education.
Their proximity to mosques highlights the religious motivations underpinning madrasa construction and the blend of educational and religious institutions.
Students who completed their education at the lower medreses were called danismends.
Similar to today's educational systems, the Ottoman system comprised various school levels, requiring students to advance from lower to more specialized madaris to prepare for higher learning.
To fortify the dynasty's grip on Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia.
He successfully repelled Galdan's forces from these territories, subsequently incorporating them into the empire.

Galdan met his end during the Dzungar–Qing War. In 1683, Qing forces secured the surrender of Taiwan from Zheng Keshuang, grandson of Koxinga, who had seized Taiwan from Dutch colonists to use as a base against the Qing.
Zheng Keshuang was granted the title "Duke Haicheng" (海澄公) and joined the Han Chinese Plain Red Banner of the Eight Banners upon his relocation to Beijing.
Several Ming princes had accompanied Koxinga to Taiwan in 1661-1662, including the Prince of Ningjing Zhu Shugui and Prince Zhu Honghuan (朱弘桓), son of Zhu Yihai, residing in the Kingdom of Tungning.
In 1683, the Qing transported the 17 remaining Ming princes from Taiwan back to mainland China, where they lived in exile but were spared execution.
The capture of Taiwan allowed Kangxi's forces to concentrate on battles over Albazin, a remote outpost of the Russian Tsardom.
Former soldiers from Zheng's Taiwan forces, like the rattan shield troops, were integrated into the Eight Banners and deployed against Russian Cossacks at Albazin.
The 1689 Treaty of Nerchinsk was China's first formal treaty with a European power, securing a peaceful border for nearly two centuries.
After Galdan's death, his followers, adherents of Tibetan Buddhism, sought to influence the selection of the next Dalai Lama.
In response, Kangxi sent two armies to Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, to install a Qing-friendly Dalai Lama.
Following the death of President Benito Juárez in 1872, Vice-President Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada assumed the presidency and called for new elections.
The two candidates were Lerdo de Tejada and General Porfirio Díaz, a renowned hero of the Battle of Puebla on May 5, 1862.
Lerdo de Tejada won the election but lost favor when he announced plans to seek re-election.
On March 21, 1876, Porfirio Díaz launched a rebellion against President Lerdo de Tejada, advocating for the "No Re-election" principle through the Plan of Tuxtepec.
On June 2, 1876, the garrisons in Chihuahua state surrendered to Díaz's authority, resulting in the arrest of Governor Antonio Ochoa and the suppression of Lerdista forces across the state.
Díaz then supported the reinstatement of Tíras as the governor of Chihuahua, facilitating the implementation of the Plan of Tuxtepec.
This victory led to Jose Maria Iglesias briefly holding the interim presidency until Díaz, as the sole candidate, became president on May 5, 1877.
In the early years of Díaz's administration, known as the Porfiriato, his government faced attacks from both Lerdista forces and Apache groups.
Exiled Lerdistas orchestrated a new rebellion from the United States, temporarily capturing the city of El Paso del Norte until mid-1877.
That year, the northern region suffered a severe drought, causing many deaths in El Paso del Norte.

In December 2015, Kanye West released a song titled "Facts." By January 2016, he announced on Twitter that his album SWISH would be out on February 11, along with releasing "Real Friends" and a snippet of "No More Parties in L.A." featuring Kendrick Lamar.
This marked the revival of the GOOD Fridays initiative, where Kanye would release new singles every Friday.
On January 26, West renamed the album from SWISH to Waves and announced the debut of his Yeezy Season 3 clothing line at Madison Square Garden.
Weeks before his album release, West engaged in a brief social media feud with rapper Wiz Khalifa, which involved their mutual ex Amber Rose.
Rose contested West's comments involving her and Khalifa's child, leading to media coverage of her allegations about her relationship with West.
By February 2, West and Khalifa had reconciled. Shortly before the album's release, West changed the title again to The Life of Pablo.

He premiered the album on February 11 at Madison Square Garden during his Yeezy Season 3 presentation, announcing further track list changes and delaying the release to refine the track "Waves" at the request of co-writer Chance the Rapper.
The album debuted exclusively on Tidal on February 14, 2016, following a performance on SNL.
Since 1898, the KU men's basketball team has consistently been in the game. Known as the Jayhawks, they're perennial national contenders, currently led by coach Bill Self.
With five national titles to their name, the team boasts three NCAA tournament championships from 1952, 1988, and 2008.
By the end of the 2011–12 season, Kansas had amassed an overall record of 2,070 wins and 806 losses, making it the second-winningest program in college basketball history.
They play at the renowned Allen Fieldhouse. Among their most famous players was Wilt Chamberlain, who starred in the 1950s.

Kansas's coaching roster has included legendary figures like Dr. James Naismith, the inventor of basketball and the only KU coach with a losing record; Phog Allen, revered as "the Father of basketball coaching"; Roy Williams, a Hall of Fame inductee and former North Carolina coach; and Larry Brown, another Hall of Fame inductee and former NBA champion coach with the Detroit Pistons.

Furthermore, renowned Kentucky coach Adolph Rupp, a Hall of Fame inductee, and Dean Smith, an NCAA Hall of Fame inductee and former North Carolina coach, both played for KU's championship teams in 1922, 1923, and 1952.
Rupp and Smith were coached by Phog Allen, who also mentored Hall of Famers Ralph Miller and Dutch Lonborg.

Allen was instrumental in founding the National Association of Basketball Coaches (NABC), which initiated the NCAA Tournament in 1939 before handing it over to the newly established NCAA the following year.

In July 1645, Dorgon issued a contentious edict, known as the "haircutting order," requiring adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and style the remaining hair into a queue, similar to that worn by Manchu men.
Failure to comply meant death. The edict was famously summarized as: "To keep the hair, you lose the head; to keep your head, you cut the hair."
For the Manchus, this policy served as a loyalty test and a way to identify allies.

However, for the Han Chinese, it was a humiliating symbol of Qing dominance, clashing with traditional Confucian values outlined in the Classic of Filial Piety (Xiaojing), which stated that "a person's body and hair, as gifts from one's parents, should not be harmed."
Under the preceding Ming dynasty, men wore their hair in top-knots and did not cut it.
The edict sparked fierce resistance to Qing rule in Jiangnan, leading to mass killings of Han Chinese.
Ironically, it was Han Chinese defectors who carried out massacres against those refusing the queue.
Li Chengdong, a former Ming general who surrendered to the Qing, commanded his troops to perform three separate massacres in Jiading within a month, resulting in tens of thousands of deaths.

By the end of the third massacre, scarcely anyone in the city remained alive. Jiangyin resisted the Qing forces for 83 days, but when the city walls fell on October 9, 1645, the Qing army, led by Ming defector Liu Liangzuo (劉良佐), massacred the entire population, killing between 74,000 and 100,000 people, under orders to "fill the city with corpses before you sheathe your swords."
The queue was the only element of Manchu culture imposed on the general Han populace.
While officials were required to wear Manchu attire, ordinary Han civilians were permitted to continue wearing Hanfu.

The Defence Committee's Third Report, "Defence Equipment 2009," references an article from the Financial Times website, noting that General Sir Kevin O’Donoghue, Chief of Defence Materiel, directed Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) staff via an internal memo to reprioritize the approvals process.

This refocusing emphasizes support for current operations over the next three years, deterrence-related programs, defense obligations that are either contractual or international, and projects with signed production contracts.

The report also highlights concerns about potential cuts to the defence science and technology research budget, inaccurate estimates of Defence Inflation impacting budgets, underfunding in the Equipment Programme, and the challenge of balancing short-term focuses on current operations with the need to invest in future UK defense capabilities.
Bob Ainsworth MP, the then Secretary of State for Defence, endorsed this shift towards current operations, mentioning that "major shifts" in defense spending were not off the table.

Admiral Sir Mark Stanhope, First Sea Lord and Chief of the Naval Staff, acknowledged the insufficient funding in the defense budget, indicating the necessity for tough decisions and possible cutbacks.

According to the London Evening Standard, the 2009 defense budget was "more than 10% overspent," though these figures are unverified, prompting Gordon Brown to declare the need for defense spending cuts.
To manage costs and enhance services for its personnel, the Ministry of Defence has been investing in IT.

After Windows 8 was unveiled, Microsoft faced criticism, mainly from free software advocates, for requiring devices seeking optional Windows 8 certification to have secure boot enabled by default with a key provided by Microsoft.
Critics worried that secure boot might restrict the use of alternative operating systems like Linux.
On the Building Windows 8 blog, Microsoft developer Tony Mangefeste addressed these concerns, noting that vendors would offer ways to customize secure boot.
He emphasized, "At the end of the day, the customer is in control of their PC. Microsoft's philosophy is to provide the best experience first, allowing customers to make their own decisions."
Microsoft's certification guidelines for Windows 8 clarified that vendors must allow users to reconfigure or disable secure boot in their device's UEFI firmware.
However, the guidelines also mandated that ARM devices (running Windows RT) keep secure boot permanently enabled, preventing users from disabling it.
Tom Warren from The Verge observed that other vendors had similar restrictions on their ARM-based tablets and smartphones, including those using Microsoft's Windows Phone platform.
He argued, however, that Microsoft should "maintain consistency across ARM and x86 platforms," particularly due to many users hoping to run Android alongside Windows 8 on their future tablets.
There were no requirements for installing third-party certificates to run alternative programs.
Kanye West's middle-class background, flamboyant fashion sense, and outspoken nature have distinguished him from other rappers.
Early in his career, West was one of the first to openly criticize the pervasive homophobia in hip hop.
The sales rivalry between 50 Cent's "Curtis" and West's "Graduation" changed hip hop's trajectory, opened doors for new artists, and broke away from the hardcore gangster mold.
Rosie Swash of The Guardian regarded this competition as a pivotal moment, highlighting hip hop's divergent trends: gangsta rap for the 2000s versus West's intellectual alternative.
Rolling Stone attributed West with transforming mainstream hip hop by creating introspective yet polished rap.

They described him as one of the most intriguing and complex pop stars of the 2000s—a rapper who mastered and then transcended the hip hop scene, a producer with a distinctive sound that he left for his imitators, and a flashy yet insightful figure discussing college, culture, and economics.
His 2008 album, "808s & Heartbreak," divided listeners and critics but was a commercial success.

It had a stylistic impact on hip hop and pop, paving the way for artists like Frank Ocean, The Weeknd, Drake, Future, Kid Cudi, Childish Gambino, Lil Durk, Chief Keef, and Soulja Boy, who favored introspection over traditional rap braggadocio.

Ben Detrick of XXL magazine noted that West led a new wave of artists, such as Kid Cudi, Wale, Lupe Fiasco, Kidz in the Hall, and Drake, who were uninterested in or incapable of rapping about gunplay or drug dealing.

In 633 AD, the Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran, conquering it by 651 AD. This led to a significant conversion of Iranians from their indigenous faiths, such as Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism, to Sunni Islam.
Arabic became the official language, though Persian persisted as the language of the people and literature.
Iran played a crucial role in the Islamic Golden Age, contributing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers.

The rise of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501 marked a shift as Iranians were converted from Sunni to Twelver Shia Islam, establishing it as the official religion and representing a significant turning point in Iranian and Muslim history.
Under Nader Shah in 1736, Iran reached its largest territorial expansion since the Sassanid Empire, briefly becoming one of the era's most powerful empires.
In the 19th century, Iran lost extensive territories in the Caucasus to Imperial Russia, lands that had been part of its identity for centuries.
Popular unrest led to the Persian Constitutional Revolution of 1906, ushering in a constitutional monarchy and the country's first parliament (Majles).
A coup d'état in 1953, backed by the U.K. and the U.S., aligned Iran closely with the West, maintaining a secular but increasingly autocratic government.
Widespread dissatisfaction with foreign influence and political repression fueled the 1979 Revolution, resulting in the establishment of an Islamic republic on April 1, 1979.
The largest military engagement involving the United States during this period was the War of 1812.
Britain, deeply embroiled in a war against Napoleon's France, aimed to block American trade with France, while the U.S. tried to remain neutral and continue its overseas commerce.
Despite strong protests, Britain impeded this trade and forcibly conscripted American sailors into the Royal Navy.
Additionally, Britain supported an Indian uprising in the American Midwest, intending to establish an Indian state that would hinder U.S. expansion.
Finally, in 1812, the United States declared war on the United Kingdom for the first time, though not expecting to best the Royal Navy.
Instead, the U.S. invaded British Canada, hoping to leverage captured territory for negotiation.
This invasion was disastrous, although simultaneous conflicts with Native Americans in the west, such as Tecumseh's War and the Creek War, saw more success.
Following Napoleon's defeat in 1814, Britain dispatched large veteran forces to invade New York, raid Washington, and seize control of the Mississippi River at New Orleans.
The New York campaign ended in failure as the sizable British army retreated to Canada.
The British raid successfully burned Washington on August 25, 1814, but they were repelled in the Chesapeake Bay Campaign at the Battle of Baltimore, where their commander was killed.
In Louisiana, a decisive battle at New Orleans dealt a crushing blow to Britain, resulting in the deaths of their top three generals and thousands of soldiers.
This victory was a defining moment for Major General Andrew Jackson, who later became president, and for Americans celebrated for triumphing over a formidable foe.
The peace treaty was effective, and the U.S. and Britain never again went to war.
However, the Indians suffered as they did not receive the independent territory in the Midwest promised by Britain.
Many modern specialty matches have been designed with distinct winning conditions.
One of the most popular is the ladder match, where wrestlers or wrestling teams must climb a ladder to retrieve a prize suspended above the ring.
To win, a wrestler or team must incapacitate their opponents long enough for a member to climb the ladder and secure the prize. Consequently, the ladder often becomes a weapon.
Typical prizes include a championship belt (the traditional reward), a document granting a future title shot, or anything significant to the wrestlers, such as a cash prize.
Another popular specialty match is the battle royal, where all wrestlers enter the ring until it fills with around 20-30 contestants.
Once the match begins, each wrestler's goal is to throw opponents over the top rope, landing them outside the ring with both feet on the floor to eliminate them.

The last wrestler remaining wins. A variation of this match is WWE's Royal Rumble, where two wrestlers start, and others enter at 90-second intervals (formerly 2 minutes) until 30-40 wrestlers are in the ring.
All other rules remain the same. For more match types, see Professional wrestling match types.
The university culture in northern Europe evolved differently from that in the south, despite sharing many elements, such as the use of Latin for texts, lectures, debates, and exams.
Northern universities, primarily in Germany, France, and Great Britain, focused on the arts and theology, while southern universities, notably in Italy, emphasized law and medicine.
Instruction quality reflected these focuses, prompting scholars to travel based on their interests and resources.
Northern universities often awarded bachelor's degrees, especially outside theology, where doctorates were more common.
In contrast, Italian universities primarily conferred doctorates, reflecting career intentions: teaching in the north and professional roles in the south.

The governance structures also differed; northern universities followed the faculty-governed model of the University of Paris, whereas southern universities adopted the student-controlled model of the University of Bologna.

Additionally, a distinction existed among southern institutions: northern Italian universities, like Bologna, operated as independent scholar corporations, while those in southern Italy and Iberia were established by royal or imperial charters to meet government needs.
In the spring of 1800, Napoleon led his troops across the Swiss Alps into Italy, aiming to catch the Austrian armies off guard.
These forces had reclaimed the peninsula while Napoleon was in Egypt. Despite the challenging Alpine crossing, the French army entered the plains of Northern Italy with little resistance.
Meanwhile, another French army faced a siege in Genoa by a substantial Austrian force.
The fierce resistance led by André Masséna in Genoa bought valuable time for Napoleon's forces in the north.
After days of maneuvering, the French and Austrian armies finally clashed at the Battle of Marengo on June 14.
General Melas commanded about 30,000 Austrian troops, outnumbering Napoleon's 24,000 soldiers.
Initially, the battle favored the Austrians, who surprised the French, pushing them back.
Believing victory was secured, Melas withdrew to his headquarters around 3 p.m., leaving the pursuit to his subordinates.
However, Napoleon's leadership during the tactical retreat kept his troops from breaking.
Late in the afternoon, Desaix's full division arrived, turning the battle in the French's favor.
A combination of artillery barrages and timely cavalry charges shattered the Austrian forces, which retreated in disarray over the Bormida River back to Alessandria, leaving behind 14,000 casualties.
The next day, the Austrians agreed to withdraw from Northern Italy under the Convention of Alessandria, securing safe passage in exchange for their regional fortresses.
Vladimir was the Prince of Novgorod at the time of his father Sviatoslav I's death in 972.
In 976, he fled to Scandinavia after his half-brother Yaropolk killed their brother Oleg and seized control of Rus.
In Scandinavia, Vladimir, with the aid of his relative Earl Håkon Sigurdsson, the ruler of Norway, gathered a Viking army to reclaim Novgorod and Kiev from Yaropolk.
As Prince of Kiev, Vladimir's key achievement was the Christianization of Kievan Rus', commencing in 988.
The Primary Chronicle notes that when Vladimir decided to adopt a new religion instead of the Slavs' traditional idol worship, he dispatched trusted advisors and warriors to various parts of Europe.
They explored the Latin Rite Christians, Jews, and Muslims before reaching Constantinople.
They dismissed Islam due to its ban on alcohol and Judaism because it seemed its God had allowed His people to lose their homeland.
The Roman church ceremonies appeared uninspiring to them. However, the grandeur of Hagia Sophia and the liturgical service in Constantinople captivated them, leading them to choose this faith.
Upon returning home, they persuaded Vladimir that the Byzantine Rite was the ideal choice.
Consequently, Vladimir traveled to Constantinople to arrange a marriage with Princess Anna, sister of Byzantine Emperor Basil II.
The desert sky is typically clear, and sunshine is abundant throughout the Sahara, with most areas receiving over 3,600 hours of bright sunshine annually, equating to more than 82% of the time.
In the eastern Sahara, certain regions surpass 4,000 hours of sunshine each year, or over 91% of the time, approaching the theoretical maximum.
Upper Egypt (Aswan, Luxor) and the Nubian Desert (Wadi Halfa) record about 4,300 hours or 98% sunshine annually.
Direct solar irradiation averages around 2,800 kWh/m² per year in the Great Desert, indicating vast potential for solar energy production.

The sun's consistent high position, exceptionally low humidity, and scarce vegetation and rainfall render the Great Desert the world’s hottest continuously large area, with summer temperatures often peaking as the hottest spots on Earth.
Average high temperatures in most desert areas exceed 38°C (100.4°F) to 40°C (104°F) during the hottest months, except at high altitudes.
The record average high temperature of 47°C (116.6°F) was noted in Bou Bernous, a remote town in the Algerian Desert at 378 meters above sea level.
